The ability of these schools to fund themselves, through their $10,000 fees, through graduand gifts, parental donations and the like, will no longer be taken into account. Their massive resource capabilities would no longer be taken into account. Instead, the addresses of parents would be examined to see whether they fall into wealthy or poor areas, as determined by a four-year-old limited census survey.

Under this system, children of millionaires who nevertheless live in relatively poor areas, such as many rural regions of Australia, will be deemed to be needy and funding to the school would be increased. Elite private schools that admit some of `the underprivileged' on scholarships will be rewarded by extra funding. It is clearly designed to get as many kids as possible out of public schools and into private schools. But this is not Dr Kemp's only motive. This is because his new funding formula does not give to private schools equally.

As many independent commentators have spotted in this legislation, the poor Catholic schools, by far the biggest group in the private school sector, are a loser in this system. We support the decision of the Catholic Education Commission to opt out of David Kemp's new system. The Catholic commission is trying to provide for the nation's 1,600 Catholic schools, some of which are among the poorest of non-government schools. We believe it is totally unfair that they should receive only an extra $157 for each Catholic school student, compared to an average $900 increase for each pupil in elite category 1 schools. The minister likes to claim he has the Catholics' support. The new funding formula has been politely received by the Catholic education authorities. They are always polite in dealing with Commonwealth governments when there is any increase at all in the resources being given to them. But make no mistake: they are alert to the dangers of the new so-called socioeconomic status—or SES—funding. As the Deputy Chair of the National Catholic Education Commission, Father Tom Doyle, said on August 22:

quote.para: We would still maintain that the SES model in itself was not sufficient and that it needs modification ... that is why we talk about SES plus things like resource indicators and resource availabilities.

speech.para: Precisely what I have been talking about. We have had it confirmed by high-level education officials that the top 62 schools in Australia will get $50 million extra to share, while the 1,600 Catholic schools receive only $100 million per annum extra. Top category 1 schools, like the ones most of the government frontbench went to, do very nicely, while those in the local Sacred Heart Convent, like the ones at least 40 per cent of my frontbench went to, hardly get enough for a couple of library books. It looks as if David Kemp has taken a spiritual point from St Matthew's Gospel literally as an issue in public policy:

quote.para: For unto every one that hath shall be given, and he shall have abundance: but from him that hath not shall be taken away, even that which he hath.

speech.para: The origins of David Kemp's position lie deep in history. His views are of a piece with the Liberal Party's opposition to state aid—a debate resolved by my father in the 1970s. The Liberals opposed needs based funding then, and today Dr Kemp has found a formula to try to get back to those days. I remember them well. I remember my father telling me that Malcolm Fraser leant across the dispatch box while he introduced his bills and said to him, `You will not get these bills. They will be defeated in the Senate.' What he was saying was that the poor schools of Australia would not get that funding. They got it after my father was hospitalised with a heart attack, when Lionel Bowen, who in many ways is a more worldly figure than my father, went around to the National Party and gave them a list of the Catholic schools in their electorates which he intended to visit to explain to them the consequences of the coalition's policies. And so it went through.

We in the Labor Party, as evidenced by the fact that we are the authors, are not opposed to private schools receiving a decent share of federal funds. My father's reforms ensured that people who pay their taxes to see a proportion of their money go to the schools attended by their children get some just reward—it is only fair. But we do not support the inequalities in David Kemp's legislation, and we know they are against every wish of ordinary, decent Australians. We know that education is a fundamental concern of Australians and that it is getting more important in this society to get a good education. What we in the Labor Party believe, unlike our opponents, is that a good education is not just a private desire; it is a public investment for the public good. There is simply nothing more important for the future of this country than a good education system. We know, although our government cannot seem to grasp it, that we cannot afford to let our education system run down.

The public system, which the majority of Australians will continue to attend, lies at the heart of our commitment to education. We need every child from every family to get the basic building blocks to allow them to take their place in the revolution going on in our workplaces. We are already 30,000 information technology workers short in this country. We desperately need more science and engineering graduates, as well as more and better teachers in `enabling sciences'. Does David Kemp think they are all going to come out of 62 elite schools? Whenever we raise public education as a national concern, he comes in and makes patronising comments about how the government has some technical education programs or traineeships for the poorer areas of Australia. Of course, many of these programs were begun by Labor in any case. We agree that these programs are essential and that this country needs well-educated, technical trainees. But we need much more than that. We cannot just sit back and hope that somehow we will muddle through, that our education system may, through luck, manage to produce enough high-technology, science-literate, innovative and adaptable workers for the knowledge economy.

As our competitors around the world know, it takes planning, it takes investment and it takes something this government has never had—a commitment to equality of opportunity. The population of this nation is too small to go backwards to David Kemp's notion of the elite—those who deserve the best because they were born into the right families. We need to get the best out of everyone—the kids of struggling working families in the west of Sydney; children of farmers battling to break even in the bush; and sons and daughters of Australians who believe in the public system, who pay their taxes and who want their schools improved.

The minister often comes into this House and takes refuge in what he perceives to be the failure of public school teachers, yet these people are the backbone of many communities in this nation. For modest pay, these teachers take on big classes, literacy and numeracy problems, sports and music needs, discipline issues and a rapidly changing curriculum. Besides those, these folk take on many of the essential organisational requirements—the sporting, social and voluntary activities—of the towns of regional Australia. I well remember when the Teachers Union in Western Australia organised a work-to-rule to pursue their case. The people who were first to complain about it were all the country football teams that lost their coaches and the local fire brigades that lost their workers. One after the other these teachers, so demonised by this minister, had their full public value drawn to the attention of the bulk of the Australian community in generally Liberal voting electorates.

We all know there are problems. As the government's chief scientist reported recently, many teachers are being forced to teach subjects they are not trained in. It is impossible to excite growing kids into an interest in science and maths—the building blocks of the knowledge revolution—if you do not have any background in these subjects and you are two or three lessons ahead of them. All of the latest research suggests that the best way to improve education is not to change the state and private split, as Dr Kemp believes, but to improve the subject expertise of teachers and to attract high calibre graduates to teaching, with a particular but not exclusive emphasis on science, maths and information technology skills.

We have already begun to address these problems. We have announced details of our teacher development contracts and our teacher excellence scholarships. We will work with communities in disadvantaged areas to introduce education priority zones to lift the quality of education in the areas that need it most. We will assist students, teachers and parents through new technology, with our Learning Gateway web site, giving instant access to a huge range of educational services and a thorough understanding to parents about where their children are going, the sort of curriculum that they are dealing with, where that curriculum will take them and the sorts of tests they will be obliged to confront. That is real community knowledge and community participation, and it will underpin those priority zones, which will be community based. Communities will determine their needs. That need may be for additionally qualified teachers, it may be for special literacy programs or it may be for mentoring programs into ultimate traineeships or onto university. There is a whole range of things—one size does not fit all—in our communities, and this will address them. We will double the number of educational research scholarships at universities, an idea recently taken up by the chief scientist. Beyond this, we will introduce a new category of fellowships to keep the best and brightest Australians here.

Here is something that will be popular with almost everyone in the debate: we will abolish the hated enrolment benchmark adjustment. We will not penalise our public system because of an ideological fixation. Here is the central issue at stake: the minister has to explain to Australians, in a context of scarce public resources, how giving $50 million to category 1 private schools will be a more effective policy than improving opportunities for ordinary kids throughout this country. Until we get an answer to this, we will be seeking to adjourn debate on this legislation. It is an insult for this parliament to be asked to pass a $22 billion bill before the government provides detailed final figures on the bill's true financial effect. We are supposed to be the checkpoint of the accountability of legislation before us. If we cannot get a complete and clear picture of how this very confused model produces a particular outcome for individual schools, no-one can get it. We have an absolute right as the House of Representatives to demand that prior to passage of these bills.

We are not alone in our criticisms. If the minister does not want to listen to us, there are others he might heed. Take, for example, Victorian Supreme Court Justice Frank Vincent, who is also Chancellor of Victoria University in Melbourne's western suburbs. Justice Vincent, who came from a battling family himself and went to a state school, said on 31 August:

quote.para: I am decidedly uncomfortable with any of the processes which are increasing the practical discrimination against the poor in this country, and I fear that might be happening at the present time with these new funding structures ... There were, for a period of time, avenues of opportunity for people such as myself, and I'm concerned that those avenues are being cut off dramatically as time progresses.

speech.para: It is an extraordinary statement from a man in a position to judge. We are going backwards in equity. There has been widespread community outcry about the unfairness of the minister's aims. The Melbourne Age, in a blistering editorial, said:

quote.para: The government's new socioeconomic status funding system for private schools, which will provide the massive windfall gains for the richest schools, will only entrench the disparities within our education system. It is not in the best interests of the nation to go down this path.

speech.para: The Australian, often a supporter of the government's market driven policies, was equally scathing:

quote.para: The reforms are tantamount to conceding defeat in the battle to improve the quality of education available to all. The Government has a duty to spend taxpayers' money where it does most good, for those who need it most. Dr Kemp's system leaves the elite the richer and education the poorer.

speech.para: This is a massive indictment. The commentators know it, the education industry knows it and students, teachers and parents know it. It is time for the government to wake up to itself. Under the Howard government, the policy—as in so many other areas—is for the rich to get richer, the poor to get poorer and the middle to be squeezed. Under the Howard education regime, it's back to the four Rs—Reading, 'Riting and 'Rithmetic for the Rich. That is the antithesis to Labor's approach, and that is why we want this debate adjourned—so we can have a proper discussion on the public investment issues associated with education.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. May I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his opening comments if for no other part of his speech. I certainly agree that we should be aspiring to be a knowledge nation and that every student deserves the opportunity for an education. I disagree strongly, though, that if education in the government sector falls down it is completely the fault of a federal government. I say this about Labor: when they get into state government, they know how to cut back funding. The increase in the federal budget for education is 4.2 per cent. The member for Lilley may well remember from his experience in assisting state governments that this year the increase in the Queensland state government budget for education is 0.8 per cent. Let me say those figures again: federal government increase, 4.2 per cent; Labor state government in Queensland increase, 0.8 per cent.

speech.para: It has always been the responsibility of a state government to look after government education, and it has always been the responsibility of the federal government, in the main, to look after non-government education. That is how you create the health of the whole system. It is not, as the Leader of the Opposition asserts, through attacking one section while you build up the other.

talk.start.para: —There are no category 1 schools in Toowomba!

—You do not strengthen the weak by weakening the strong, member for Batman. I can tell you that when Labor were in power they did everything they could to destroy the non-government sector of education in this nation. We are about building up both sides of education. We in the coalition believe in a choice in education. Whether the Premier of Queensland wants to send his son to Brisbane Grammar is not in the equation I am talking about tonight. The equation I am talking about tonight is the one that gives parents freedom of choice in which school their children are educated. One of my daughters is educated at a government school and the other is educated at a non-government school. Both those schools provide exceptional levels of education. I defy anyone to show me a better school than Toowoomba East State School, under the leadership of Alan Jarrott.

speech.para: We heard a tirade against the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs from the Leader of the Opposition that was completely unjustified. This government policy we are debating at the moment has never been driven by ideological obsession; it has been driven by a desire to bring equity, fairness and transparency to the education system. We want to ensure that schools are given ample opportunity to provide a standard of education that is fair and equitable. I noted the comments of the Leader of the Opposition about Catholic schools. Yes, they are happy. The reason they are happy is that they will get $8.15 billion out of this federal government, of the $13 billion that is allocated to non-government schools. Of course, all educators want more. Every school I go to wants more money. It does not matter whether it is a government or a non-government school. What we as a federal government are doing is addressing those needs.

Last night during the adjournment debate I discussed some of the great programs that the federal government is involved in. I spoke about the $529,000 that we have just given to a government school at Fairview Heights in my electorate, the $70,000 that we have given to Sacred Heart School in Toowoomba and the $170,000 that we have given to the St Francis de Sales school in Clifton. What that tells me—and I know from looking in my diary that I am going to the Wilsonton School when parliament adjourns—is that we are continuing to fund on a fair and equitable basis, with a commitment to equal opportunity.

We, like the Leader of the Opposition, want to see all schools improved. We want to see the standard we have at the moment improved. What I see in government schools in my electorate is already an exceptional standard of schooling. Attending the speech nights at the end of last year—perhaps something that many of us do not look forward to, a string of late nights in a row, but I can say that I get a great deal of satisfaction in going along and seeing the potential that these young people have and the great education they receive—my observations were that the government schools in my electorate are easily on a par with the non-government schools.

That is not to say that there is not a shift in my electorate, as there is in Australia, towards non-government schools. That is part of offering the choice. I think that the Leader of the Opposition may echo his words when he says that governments have a responsibility to spend taxpayers' money where it does the most good. We are certainly doing that. We are doing it in such a way that those parents who make the decision to educate their children in non-government schools are actually saving the taxpayers money. For every child whose education is supported by the federal government and by Australia's taxpayers, for every dollar that we put in there, we save 50c, compared with what we spend on a student who studies in a government school. That is about delivering maximum bang for your buck. That is an issue that the Labor Party in this parliament do not understand. It is an issue that they had extraordinary difficulty in understanding when it came to health insurance. We make no bones about the fact that a government has a responsibility to ensure that the choice remains for parents and that, if parents make that choice—and many of the parents who make a choice to use non-government schools do so at great financial hardship—we as a government have a responsibility to support them.

In supporting this bill to implement the government's commitment to maintaining stability in Commonwealth funding for primary and secondary education in Australia for the 2001-2004 quadrennium, I emphasise the federal government's commitment to giving parents the choice of whether their children are educated in a government or a non-government school. I am therefore happy to reiterate on the record, and I have probably done so already, that the federal government is committed to ensuring that choice and to ensuring that all Australian children receive the best education possible.

A fair funding model is vital if we are to meet the challenge of continuing to achieve our commitment to delivering the best possible education for our nation's students. The answer to this challenge lies in the introduction of the SES system. The SES funding assessment arrangements are designed to more fairly, simply and transparently determine the funding needs of non-government schools, at no cost to government schools. Rather than using the schools' own resource levels, as measured by the current and clearly discredited ERI system—a system that unfairly froze funding to non-government schools for up to 15 years in some cases—SES assessment will consider the parents' capacity to pay.

I know the Labor Party has difficulty in understanding this process, so I will say it again. SES funding is money which goes to schools according to the independently assessed needs of families whose children are enrolled there. I cannot for the life of me understand why the Labor Party is running around telling everyone that money is going to the wealthy schools. The Leader of the Opposition quoted in his address this mythical figure of 62 schools. The Labor Party is running around saying that all this money is going to the wealthy schools. This is wedge politics at its cheapest—at its cheapest. We hear the rhetoric coming from the Leader of the Opposition that the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. Is he so desperate now that he has to resort to dividing this nation? Isn't leadership, in the true sense of the word, about uniting the nation, about bringing the systems together? Isn't that what leadership is about? I must admit my disappointment at seeing the Leader of the Opposition stoop so low.

It is unfortunate that Labor and some of those who supposedly represent the many tremendous Australian teachers have done so much to try to discredit what the federal government is doing. In that situation, I am proud and pleased that the coalition government remains totally committed to the stability of the education system, while the Labor Party continues to try to pull down the non-government sector. To illustrate the point, there was recently a letter to the editor in the Toowoomba Chronicle, in my electorate of Groom, which espoused this theory. Surprise, surprise—it came from the teachers' union in Queensland. It said that we, the government, are taking money from the government schools and putting it into the non-government schools—no facts, no figures; it just makes the statement and then turns and runs.

I had to do some research to respond to that letter, and I was able to show quite clearly to the readers of the Toowoomba Chronicle, and hopefully to all at large, that in fact the federal government's funding commitment to government schools in Queensland has risen from $290 million per annum, when the coalition took office in 1996, to $385 million per annum now. Under this government, that figure is projected to reach $443 million in 2004. The federal government's $1.9 billion per annum commitment to state government schooling is rock solid and is part of our 4.2 per cent increase in education spending as outlined in our budget.

I have had the pleasure in recent times of visiting a number of schools in my electorate. I picked up an imputation in the Leader of the Opposition's speech that the standard in government schools was declining, but I have not seen it. When I go to government schools, I see schools that are full of committed people. I see communities like the one at Fairview Heights, which I spoke of earlier, where the teachers are completely committed, and the standard is improving all the time. The outcomes that they are achieving there, with a combination of state and federal government funding, are outcomes we can all be proud of. I see a school in a new suburb taking on some of the teaching challenges that always present themselves in communities, and the use of mixed classes, where the older students assist the younger students as part of a process of helping those students who are having difficulty in learning, is something that I commend. As I said, I visit state schools regularly, and I have to say that I have seen no evidence at all of a slip in standards at government schools in my electorate.

I guess that poses the question of why parents are moving from government schools to non-government schools. It is an issue of freedom of choice. After all, parents will always aspire to do what is best for their children, and that best does not always relate to the standard of education in terms of the three Rs. It can come from decisions relating to spiritual beliefs, discipline, whether or not they want their son or daughter to attend a same sex school, curriculum choice, parental involvement and even sporting opportunities. I do not in any way resile from the fact that the federal government will continue to assist government schools as we work to ensure that non-government schools are able to rebuild themselves from the catastrophe of funding that occurred under the previous Labor government.

The suggestion that students in non-government schools come from rich parents is one which I despise intensely. In my electorate, where we have a number of poorer schools—all of which will benefit from this legislation—I am sure those parents will take equal offence at the comments from the Leader of the Opposition. It is interesting to look at the Bureau of Statistics figures which show that 21 per cent of school students in non-government schools come from families with an annual income of less than $26,000. It makes this statement about rich parents look pretty silly to me.

The government remains unruffled by these constant attacks coming forward from the Labor Party. The bottom line remains that there is simply no evidence of a move away from our commitment to government schools. On the issue of the EBA, which Labor like to try to run with, it is interesting to read some detail about how the states are reacting to the EBA and it is interesting also to note that the Ministerial Council on Employment, Education, Training And Youth Affairs acknowledges that the EBA's real purpose is about preventing cost shifting. What we are really trying to do with the EBA is to ensure that the state governments do not start pocketing the money which we are giving to them for the education of students who have moved into non-government schools which we then fund through another stream. The sort of thing that we regularly see—overlooked, though, by the Labor Party—is that in that formula we do not take back the total amount of the EBA; in fact, we only take half. Of course, it is another area that, when pressed, the state governments will acknowledge.
It is not just the federal government that wishes to see this legislation carried. Let me read from a letter that I received last week from the Australian Parents Council which says:

quote.para: The Bill recognises that every child is entitled to a base level of public funding for their school education. It provides a fairer way of giving parents at all income levels a chance of choosing the most appropriate schooling for their children. The Bill gives more equitable Commonwealth funding to non-government school students and is based on a more transparent measure of educational need. Commonwealth funding for non-government students and schools is linked to Average Government School Recurrent Cost (AGSRC). So it can be easily seen what proportion of public money as compared with the cost of government school education, is flowing to non-government school students. The proportion ranges from 13.7% to 70% of AGSRC.

speech.para: The letter finishes by saying that:

quote.para: The Bill guarantees security of Commonwealth funding for non-government schools—

speech.para: something Labor never offered—

quote.para: and students during the phasing in of the new funding mechanism. Commonwealth funding legislation for school education runs out at the end of this year.

speech.para: And we need to see that legislation passed.

May I say that we really do need to see an end to the cheap politics being played out over children's education. This issue is far too important to allow the truth to be clouded by political gain. This issue is about ensuring that we have a fair, equitable and homogenous system which provides parents with choice—the choice of whether or not to send their children, who are far and away their biggest asset, to a government or non-government school. I reject absolutely the assertion that this government is cutting funding to government schools. I have seen no proof of it. I hear rhetoric, I hear partial quotes, I hear assertions, but I see no evidence. What I see is a federal government, as I said at the outset, committed to both government and non-government schools and to an education budget which continues to increase. It is very easy for the Leader of the Opposition to stand there and say: `We just need to spend more money on this and we just need to spend more money on that.' Of course, he has got form in that area. He spent a fair bit of money on everything when he was in charge of the purse strings—$12 billion, I think, was his best effort in terms of a budget deficit. He left us with an $80 billion deficit which we have had to deal with. Education funding is like all financial funding: it needs to be done concisely, transparently, fairly and sustainably. This bill does that, and I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —The member for Groom seems to think that, if you state an untruth often enough and loud enough, it becomes the truth. If ever two questions focused attention on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000, they were the two questions asked last Thursday by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell. The Leader of the Opposition asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs the following question:

quote.para: Minister, is it correct that funding for government schools can change for three reasons: firstly, automatic indexation for school cost increases and enrolment growth according to a formula set down by Labor in 1993; secondly, discretionary decisions to increase funding; and, thirdly, discretionary decisions to cut funding. Minister, is it correct that a senior official of the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs told the Senate last week—

speech.para: that is the previous week—

motion.para: that the total of discretionary increases for government schools was $106.4 million over the next four years? Is it not also correct that your enrolment benchmark adjustment—

speech.para: which we will abolish—

quote.para: a discretionary cut, will take more than $150 million from government schools over the next four years? Minister, is it not true that the net effect of your policy decisions, as opposed to automatic increases, is to cut funding for government schools?

speech.para: The minister's answer, of course, evaded the question. He stated contemptuously that an enrolment benchmark adjustment is not a school funding policy. What remarkable duplicity! What duplicitous denial! Yet this policy takes more than $150 million from government schools over the next four years while increasing funding by $106.4 million.

To anyone else that is a decrease in funding to government schools. I have not heard one person say anything different, except the minister and the government backbench. I have not heard one person from the independent schools or Catholic schools or low-fee Christian schools defending this appalling EBA policy. The minister is alone with his backbench and his government on this matter. He ought to be soundly condemned and pressured into resignation unless he withdraws the discriminatory policy of enrolment benchmark adjustment against government schools. The only concession to the Leader of the Opposition's question was that government school enrolments would increase by 2.3 per cent; but that will have to be achieved with considerably less funding.
The second question was asked by the shadow education minister, the member for Dobell. His question was:

quote.para: Is the minister aware that a senior official of his department told the Senate inquiry into his new school funding formula that an extra $50 million to 62 category 1 schools was `probably a good estimate'? Is the minister also aware that his enrolment benchmark adjustment has already taken more than $60 million from government schools? Minister, how can you claim that your legislation is designed to restore equity and fairness to school funding, to use your words, when it takes $60 million from government schools and gives $50 million to the 62 wealthiest schools in Australia?

speech.para: The minister, predictably, denied that this was the case. The minister explained that a reduction of $60 million from government schools—that is, the EBA—is described as a federal-state financial transaction. If that is not a funding arrangement, then I do not know what is. If that is not doublespeak in the dodgy language of the minister, then I do not know what is. It is illuminating that the minister's comments regarding the question completely failed to acknowledge the loss of funding to government schools. Why would anyone be surprised about that? The coalition's Expenditure Review Committee minutes prove that David Kemp has been on a 10-year crusade to drive students out of government schools. The member for Groom admitted that. The coalition's ERC minutes for 1991 record very clearly the intentions of the government. They state:

quote.para: He—

speech.para: that is, Dr Kemp—

quote.para: noted that the coalition sought to encourage students to move from government to non-government schools.

speech.para: Why would anyone be surprised? In the same minutes it was agreed that Dr Kemp would report back to the ERC on the subject of `non-government schools—whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and untied grants'. Since the Howard government took office in 1996, Dr Kemp has systematically implemented every one of those plans by establishing in the enrolment benchmark adjustment policy—which I have already explained has taken $60 million from government schools and will take $150 million over the next four years—by cutting untied grants to the states by more than $1.5 billion in 1996, and by now massively biasing Commonwealth funding in favour of wealthy private schools.

The minister's claim of generosity, fairness and equity towards government schools is simply fraudulent. The increases to government schools are driven by an automatic indexation formula that has been in place since 1993. If Dr Kemp had given government schools any less, he would have had to pass a budget measure to cut their funding. Another point: why is this minister asking this House to pass this bill at this time—at a time, I remind all members, when the data collection about his funding model is not complete? In fact, this is unlikely to be completed until the end of September.

The opposition have already discovered the bias towards category 1 schools at the expense of government schools. What else in the fine print of this legislation also stinks? Over a year ago the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell, asked the minister for the modelling showing the way in which the new system will distribute government funding to private schools. The shadow minister, surprisingly, received nothing. That private schools get public funding is not argued. Labor have always said we support extra funding for needy non-government schools and that we would support the new system if it were fairer. But how could anyone come to a conclusion that it would be fairer if the following takes place: the average category 1 school gets an extra $800,000 a year, the average Catholic school gets an extra $60,000 a year and the average government school gets an extra $4,000 a year? That is 200 times less. Is this what the minister means by raising education to a new level of fairness and equity? It this what the minister means by transferring funding from government schools, which 70 per cent of Australian children attend, to schools which 53 per cent of the cabinet attended—exclusive category 1 schools which cater for a small minority of privileged students?

The minister has delayed this legislation by more than 15 months. He has deliberately hidden the real figures, the real statistics, the real level of funding—that is, per capita levels—and the levels of expenditure on schools as a percentage of GDP, the only reliable measure. The minister has accused the opposition of lying. If he is to do so effectively, he needs to answer the following questions. Exactly how much additional funding will go to each of the 62 category 1 schools? When will the minister release the final figures showing the increase for each and every school in Australia to let us make a comparison? Why should category 1 schools get bigger increases than private or public schools with greater needs? How can this House be expected to vote on a $22 billion bill without knowing that information? As the shadow minister has indicated, the passage of this bill ought to be adjourned until that information is available.

This minister has, until the last couple of days, argued the mantra of freedom of maximum choice. It does not mean that at all; it means according to the ability of people to pay. That is for whom freedom of choice is a viable option. As I said earlier, the minister has now introduced a new mantra. In fact it was last week when he had the gall to state that he intended to raise fairness and equity to a new level in Australia. And pigs might fly! This bill does nothing for disabled children. This bill does nothing for rural children. This bill does nothing for children in socioeconomically depressed areas. This is a great sadness because this government promised to govern for all Australians.

This government's action in education is a threat to our Australian democracy founded on the secular state, founded on non-discriminatory universal access to education, founded on widely shared knowledge, values and justice for all, and funded on equal education opportunity. That is what is really threatened, and that is a threat to all of us. It is not just the Labor opposition and the AEU saying this; many academics have spoken out about the direction this government has taken and the risk involved in pitting one group of Australians against another, of creating winners and losers in education opportunities. I have mentioned previously in this House the concerns of the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne, whose synod views with dismay the increasing polarisation between rich and poor in facilities and infrastructure provided within the government school system, exposing the more vulnerable sections of the community. They do not agree with the government's new schools policy either. Their report The state of our state schools, which was published in August 1998, states:

quote.para: In the interests of social cohesion it would be better that the proliferation of small, low-fee private schools (many with sectional interests) cease.

speech.para: The Anglican Diocese of Melbourne obviously do not give any credence to the minister's mantra on choice either. Let me quote them again:

quote.para: The present emphasis on choice should be dropped. Competition between schools increases inequalities and exacerbates social division.

speech.para: Areas of concern identified by the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne included the following: the decreased funding of government schools, the increased spending on non-government schools at the expense of government schools, and an education debate hampered by the difficulty in obtaining reliable information. That was not the Labor Party; that was not the AEU; that was not the government school sector. That was the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne—rightfully, responsibly, warning all Australians of the dangers inherent in current government policies in education. Thankfully, one responsible sector of Australian society, one not known for politicising issues, is not prepared to just look on while individualism replaces social concern and community development and the rules of the market prevail and undermine the development of community. I dare the minister and I dare any member on the government side to accuse the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne of lying as he does those of us in the Labor opposition.

This government is taking Australian education down the very slippery slope of the single market that will certainly cause failure in both the public and the private system. Behind the government's rationale for this bill is the creation of a single market in education. On the worst interpretation, this government is deceitful and malevolent as far as education is concerned. On the best interpretation, it is simply incompetent and blissfully unaware of the dangers in which it places the future of Australian society.

This government believes in blurring the distinction between public and private schools. According to Associate Professor Alan Reid of the University of South Australia, the government's central strategy is the establishment of an education quasi-market. That view is essentially shared by the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne. That is, the government seeks to create a single market in education where all schools, public or private, compete for custom. Some people respond to that proposition of a single market by saying, `So what? Won't competition in the education market make for greater efficiency?' To those people, I would say this: education is not a simply described product that can be crudely measured—it is not a tube of toothpaste, it is not a loaf of bread, it is not an automobile and it is not the latest fashion accessory.

If the logic of the creation of the single market by this government were followed, all government schools would be abolished, as a dollar spent on a private school could be argued to be more cost-effective. That is the line that the member for Groom used. The language of the single market, as used by this government, whether it be the minister, the Prime Minister or the 53 per cent of the cabinet who attended category 1 schools, is just plain wrong. A single market assumes all schools operate under similar circumstances. They do not. Private schools select students; public schools cannot. Schools that cater for children with social or economic disadvantage, behavioural disadvantage, intellectual disadvantage or physical disadvantage will never be catered for in a single market. I repeat: never in a single market.

The single market in education means the abandonment of these children. That very fact raises grave questions about the future integrity, cohesion and democracy of this nation. The marketisation of education values education only in financial terms. The intrinsic values of education—civics, responsibilities, justice—are simply ignored. This government does not appear to understand that encouraging competition between inadequately resourced schools will simply up the ante and result in increased alienation, resentment and anger. While markets obviously have an important role in our economic system, the rules of the market are simply insufficient for the government of a society.

Education is supposedly being marketised to increase efficiency, management expertise and freedom of maximum choice. What is actually happening is the deliberate reduction in real education expenditure and the devolution of responsibility to the schools themselves to reduce the political fallout for the government of the day. That some narrow sighted professional people within education departments and public schools—affluent areas, of course—support marketisation and devolution certainly muddies the water, but it does not make it right. This government is intent on setting citizens and their children into competition with each other so that there are winners and there are losers. As the Age editorial of 24 August stated:

quote.para: Dr Kemp must move beyond the rhetoric about providing choice to students and their parents and comprehend his obligation to give all children an equal chance of fulfilling their potential.

speech.para: That, of course, is yet another example to make a mockery of the minister's claim that he is raising fairness and equity to a new level. I said earlier that at worst this government is malevolent about education and at best simply incompetent. Either way, the dangers to the future of democracy are real. A single market in education, I remind the House, is antidemocratic. To meet the needs of some in education at the expense of others is antidemocratic. To increase division, separation and stratification of society is antidemocratic. The weakening of national cohesion is a threat to our democracy. To support the private purposes of schools impairs the democratic purposes of schools. If private and economic purposes are allowed to be determinants of education, as this government allows, then proposals to extend democratic purpose cannot be achieved. I repeat: they cannot be achieved. However, if democracy is to be valued, everyone in this House must defend all to be included in education, and we must do so vigorously.

This bill ought to have tackled a whole range of unsatisfactory issues—retention rates, gender imbalance, age profile of teachers, teacher training; locational disadvantage; socioeconomic disadvantage; the care of disabled children; early intervention; real literacy and numeracy skills backed up by social skills and technological skills; resource allocation according to need; differential funding rates; accountability of state governments in education; innovation and education; and reliable data with comparative longitudinal studies in education to remove the risk of so much guesswork in this country and bias in the future planning of education. But of course that would have meant integrity, fairness, equity, planning for the future, and preparing for change. Of course, that is anathema to this Prime Minister, this minister and this government.

I support the call that this debate be adjourned until all relevant information pertinent to this debate is available. This afternoon I received an interesting letter from ACSSO, the Australian Council of State School Organisations. I quote from the last page:

quote.para: One of the supporters of Dr Kemp's policies, Alan Mitchell, Economics Editor of the Australian Financial Review, let us in on what Dr Kemp's “reform” really means. He described them as promoting: “means-tested vouchers”, government schools with the “more flexible management structures of the private sector”, “publicly-owned and financed, but ...self-governing”, and “the public system more like the (expanding) private system.” He raised the possibility of means-tested funding of government schools.

speech.para: Let us go to Victoria. The letter continues:

quote.para: Two other supporters of Coalition policies, Brian Caldwell (advisor to the Kennett Government) and Don Hayward (Kennett's first minister for Education), have estimated that if these market policies are followed, only around 30% of government schools will survive. What then happens to the guarantee of a free, high quality, secular education in a local government school?

speech.para: The letter continues, saying that this government is driven by:

quote.para: ... ideological obsession with markets. The aim is to privatise provision, and to shift the costs of schooling onto parents. Around 70 % of Australian parents send their children to government schools, and public opinion polls show overwhelming public support for fully funded government schools. These policies are not supported by the Australian people—

speech.para: that is, the policies of this government—

quote.para: which is why the Coalition is trying to keep their real intent hidden.

speech.para: Secret agendas, secret documents and placing the future of this nation and our children at risk are not something to be recommended to even this government. I would hope that some people on the government side, when they join this debate, will at least have the honesty to acknowledge what the minister and this government are attempting to the great disadvantage of all of us in this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Socioeconomic status is a key predictor of educational disadvantage, although there are of course interesting exceptions as shown by studies both here and overseas. Certain migrant groups from the lowest socioeconomic status groups, among which Asian families figure prominently, do not conform to such predictions. For example, a United States study found that 30 per cent of the children of Indochinese boat people scored better than 90 per cent of American students on mathematics and only slightly less well on language skills. Another fascinating United States study found an illuminating difference between attitudes to failure at school among Caucasian Americans, Chinese Americans and People's Republic of China nationals. The first group, the Caucasian Americans, attributed failure to bad luck or bad schooling. The second group, the Chinese Americans, attributed failure to lack of effort with some allowance for other variables, and the PRC Chinese overwhelmingly put failure down to lack of effort.

speech.para: In Australia, some ethnic groups have notably outperformed Australian born students and this is even in cases where the IQ of individuals is lower and the socioeconomic status is also lower. One such group of high performers are the children of first generation immigrants of Greek peasant background with either little or no education at all. In all such cases, it seems that the key is the attitude to education held by the parents. Parents in these groups want their children to get the education they never got and they instil in their children an ideal of the value of education and of how it can be used to make a better life. Obversely, a major study in the US, the Coleman report, found that although black youths registered highly on the measure `interest in learning', their inability to imagine that any efforts of theirs could be successful meant that there was a negative correlation between years in schooling and achievement. You need to be able to imagine success before you can achieve it. The same poor Afro-Americans ascribed success more to luck than to effort. So there is a lot more to education outcomes than socioeconomic status alone but, despite the exceptions I have outlined, it has to be said that, sadly, where one is born and where one goes to school does seem to correlate with how one fares in the education system. A recent survey by the Australian Council of Educational Research found that students from poorer areas and those with less well-educated parents are opting for more vocational subjects in year 12.

This States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000 represents a sea change in funding arrangements for the school system, particularly for the growing non-government sector. It introduces new funding arrangements in the form of the SES, or socioeconomic status system, for non-government schools for the period 2001 to 2004. It is important to emphasise that this model is based on an independent assessment of the socioeconomic status of the school community and a vigorous and far-reaching consultation process with schools. The bill replaces a complex and outdated assessment of school resources, the Education Resource Index, known as the ERI. One of the problems with the ERI was that schools serving the same community could be funded at different levels under the category levels. Another was to do with disincentive. Schools wanting to raise extra funds through school fetes and the like could have their Commonwealth funding reduced in consequence. Schools were also locked into a funding level which determined their school community even if there had been fundamental changes in the socioeconomic status of that community.

The ERI, it was also universally agreed, was enormously complex. It was transparent enough when it was first introduced but over the years had built up various layers of opacity, mainly the result of political decisions that had more to do with the electoral process than with logic or rationality. When it first started, there were eight categories, then there were six and then there were 12. Each time the number changed, there were changes to the formula. At one time it measured only expenditure on recurrent resources. It later measured recurrent resources but with a check on expenditure on capital. Then it assessed only income, and after that it checked it against expenditure as well. So ERI has been described as akin to tax law in its increasing complexity over the years. Both the ERI and the new SES have this in common: they assume that Commonwealth funding should be on the basis of needs. This is the continued assumption in the new system of funding: that schools should be financed in accordance with their level of need. This needs to be stressed because otherwise we could be led astray by the overwrought rhetoric of the opposition in this chamber.

The SES model which this bill introduces is the result of consultation with state and territory governments and with both the government and non-government school sectors. The terms of reference for the review of the ERI were circulated in the period from February through to April. After this there was a further round of consultations with the states and territories and, since the introduction of the bill, a national process of consultation across all jurisdictions across all states and territories and national peak bodies between July and August. The overwhelming response from schools to the review was that the ERI mechanism no longer accurately reflected need and did not allow schools to respond to the changing needs of their communities. This was particularly a problem for rural and regional communities throughout Australia. The strong point of the new SES system is that it allows funding along a continuum to reflect the capacity of a community to support a school.

What is also a key to understanding the new system and the reason for its coming into being is the government's belief that all students are entitled to a base level of public funding, regardless of the school which they attend. This means that schools on the highest SES score will have their minimum entitlement set at 13.7 per cent of average government school recurrent costs. The maximum Commonwealth entitlement for the neediest schools and for special schools will be set at 70 per cent of average government school recurrent costs. Increased funding for schools will be phased in over four years and the government has given an undertaking that no school will be financially disadvantaged in moving to the new funding system.

This bill has two important further provisions which are quite novel. The first of these is that schools will not be penalised for raising private income, in line with the government's belief that communities should not be discouraged from providing additional resources for their schools. The second change is that distance education students in non-government schools will become eligible for Commonwealth recurrent funding set at 13.7 per cent of the average government school recurrent costs. Distance education students in the government sector already benefit from this, and this measure gives parity to those in the non-government sector in similar circumstances.

This government takes seriously its responsibility for dealing with the continuing scandal of illiteracy and innumeracy in our schools. At the end of 11 years of Labor negligence of performance assessment in the schools, up to 30 per cent of our children were finishing school unable to read or write with any proficiency. As a result of this bill, literacy and numeracy benchmarks agreed to by Commonwealth and state ministers will be incorporated into regulation. Other performance measures will also be incorporated as they are agreed to by education ministers. This emphasis on accountability and measurement of performance is part of the sea change which the Howard government has brought about in how government deals with schooling.

The opposition have made a meal out of objecting to any increase in funding for wealthy non-government schools. The points they fail to mention or to take into account in this debate are that, where schools do have high resource levels, that is due to the investment of after tax dollars in fees from parents, donations and sponsorships. This government does not believe in penalties for private investment in education. In any case, communities that have a high capacity for generating funds will be shown up in the SES index and, as a result, will get less public funding for the schools to which they send their children. The opposition have been throwing about a lot of erroneous figures about how much will be going to the most wealthy schools under the new funding arrangements. No individual school among the wealthiest 62 will be funded at an average level, as the Labor Party keeps saying. Some will receive funding at a higher level only because of the guarantee that funding will be maintained where otherwise it might have been reduced. This is to say that such wealthy schools receive that funding only because they were maintained at that level by Labor.

The Commonwealth government is increasing funding for government schools more rapidly than any state government in Australia. This is despite the fact that the states largely control funding for the government sector while the Commonwealth is responsible for the non-government sector. The Commonwealth will be spending $402 million more on government schools this year than in 1996, when the Labor Party legislated the amount of funding for government schools. This represents a 26 per cent increase by the Howard government for government schools over the past four years, yet the number of students in government schools has increased only by 2.3 per cent. Non-government organisations—Catholic and non-Catholic, independent and Christian schools—support this legislation. They see it as providing choice for working-class families.

The Catholic Education Commission have chosen to stay outside the SES system for their own reasons. They employ the SES to distribute funds within their system. The Catholic sector supports the government's legislation and has been urging the opposition to support this bill. Father Tom Doyle, Deputy Chair of the National Catholic Education Commission and Chair of the Victorian Catholic Education Commission, told the Senate committee that he:

quote.para: ... supports the [bill] ... and endorses the Commonwealth's application of the principle of need in making grants to Catholic systemically-funded schools.

speech.para: This bill is about introducing fairness, equity and social justice into our schools funding. On this side, these concepts are more than just airy nothings. The Labor Party, for all their sound and fury, are supporting this bill. I think that speaks for itself. I commend the legislation to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. But in doing so I must make the point that a Senate committee is currently inquiring into this legislation. I think it is reasonable to ask why we are debating the bill prior to the findings of that committee being released. It is a legitimate question; the government has yet to answer it in a convincing way. I make that note in passing.

speech.para: This bill represents the formal legislation for Commonwealth funding for government and non-government schools for the period 2001-04. I understand it represents appropriation of around $18 billion or, in other words, $7.6 billion for government schools and $14 billion for non-government schools. Translated into percentage figures, 35 per cent of Commonwealth-only funding for schools is directed to government schools and 65 per cent is directed to non-government schools. The bill introduces a new method of per capita funding for non-government schools. This new method of funding for non-government schools means changing from the current education resources index, ERI, which assesses a school's total resource levels, to an index which measures the socioeconomic status, SES—occupation, education and income—of all of the parents who send their children to a particular school. The SES is based on the areas of data collection of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. While introducing this new funding formula, the government is also proposing to retain the enrolment benchmark adjustment policy, the EBA.

I understand that the government conducted a simulation project in 1998 to test the theory of this new funding process. I believe that around 691 schools were involved. However, on the best available information, it seems that the simulation project threw up some interesting outcomes. At this point, I must say that not all of the details and not all of the figures are available from the government, and I must reflect upon my comments earlier in relation to the Senate committee inquiring into this legislation. It seems difficult and somewhat unacceptable for the House to be asked to consider such an incredibly important bill when a Senate inquiry is under way and when all of the figures have not yet been made available to people on this side of the House. One of the interesting outcomes of the simulation project was that three-quarters of the 691 schools involved were better off under the new system and would move to this new SES funding system. Another prediction is that the 63 wealthiest schools in Australia, presently category 1 schools, will receive some $46 million extra funding a year under this bill.

By contrast, I understand that no extra recurrent funding, other than indexation and enrolment adjustments, is provided for government schools. Also, the EBA, the enrolment benchmark adjustment process, will continue to apply. We in the Labor Party have already announced our intention to abolish the unfair EBA and to put back into government schools funding essential for their future—funding which the Howard government is planning to remove from them. The EBA has removed about $60 million from government schools in the past three years, despite the fact that those same schools have enrolled more than 26,000 extra students.

This debate is not class warfare, as the government would like everyone to believe purely on the basis of our objections; it is simply about fairness and equity. I personally do not object to it purely because some private schools seem to do well out of this funding mechanism; but I object, and I object strongly, when I see the funding formula take money from one sector and funnel that money into another sector. It is that inequity that I object to. It is simply not good enough, it is simply not acceptable, when we know that the 70 per cent of children who attend government schools will suffer as a consequence of this government's actions within this bill. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has the front to stand in this place time and again, metaphorically with his hand on his heart, and say that funding to government schools has increased under his stewardship. This is simply not the case. I do not believe that either sector—the government school system or the non-government school system—wants to have this debate. The Prime Minister and his minister for education are creating a division between them by applying this retrograde policy through this bill. We will abolish the EBA—that is an absolutely unequivocal statement—and we will invest in an honest and appropriate education system for all of our children.

An area within education which needs special consideration in this debate is that of students with disabilities. This is a constantly growing problem and a perfect example of where government attention ought to be focused. I recall a Howard government promise back in 1996 that an extra $16 million or so would go towards special education. I am not quite sure whether that was a core or a non-core promise. It must have been non-core because it disappeared, along with many other similar undertakings, between then and now. I believe this bill provides a modest increase in funding in this area for non-government schools, but it does not increase at all the overall level of funding for these students in government schools. In fact, I understand that students with disabilities attending government schools will see per capita funding decrease from $126 to $102 per year. With more than 32,000 of these students, that adds up to around $750,000 a year—a very disturbing outcome in anyone's language. How can anyone call that fair or just?

The question of students with disabilities has been in the media to a great degree in recent times, particularly with regard to some non-government schools which have been calling for increased funding to cover their obligations and their requirements when they have children with disabilities attending their schools. I would applaud their call, but I would also say that, in doing so, we must consider what is happening in the government sector as well. When you see a drop in the per capita funding for children with disabilities in government schools from $126 to $102 per year, you can only condemn any government which believes that that is a proper, appropriate, fair or just policy to apply to any student anywhere in this country. Any increase is good, but let us be honest about what is really required.

Unsurprisingly, this bill has become very contentious and has drawn many varied views from many commentators. It would also be fair to say in a very general sense that the private school sector would be more pleased with the outcome of this bill than would the government school sector. I would like to go over the figures produced, I understand, by DETYA, the department concerned, which indicate the following. The average category 1 school will get an extra $800,000 a year. The average Catholic school will get an extra $60,000 a year—that is, 12 times less. The average government school will get a real increase of around $4,000 a year—200 times less. I support fully any extra funding for needy non-government schools. I also believe very strongly in a healthy, fair and just dual system. But to have that fair, healthy and just system, we must ensure that the system is funded in a fair, healthy and just way. Taking dollars from one and funnelling them into another is not fair, just or healthy.

This country's future depends on a government investing in our education system in a proper way. Many of our trading partners are showing investment in education systems and their future that, frankly, put us to shame. Australia is the only country in the OECD where we see spending on education, training and research declining. And it is declining at a rate that no-one could applaud. This government and this minister are failing our children, are failing our future and are failing this country if they continue on this ideological bent. What we should be debating is forward thinking, progressive legislation with fair and just investment in the whole of our education system—legislation that offers hope and reward to every child participating in that education system throughout the country, regardless of their financial circumstances and regardless of where they live. Instead, we see this tawdry attempt at playing around the edges, shifting valuable resources in a crude political game and selling short our children and their educational potential.

What this minister should do is, one, abolish the inequitable and unfair EBA; two, reduce those funding increases for the ERI category 1 schools and redirect that funding to special education in both government and non-government schools; and, three, provide increases in federal funding for government schools to match the significant increases for non-government schools. This is not about trying to drive a wedge between particular sectors of this community. It is not about saying that, if you live in one area and you happen to have the right socio-economic reading from that area, you will get more or less, regardless entirely of what may be required in that area. What it is about is a government and a minister being honest, dropping the ideological cloak that at the moment is encompassing them and saying that the calls for a proper and fair approach to education in this country are correct.

The figures show the decline in investment. The figures show that some areas are far better off than others. Frankly, the policies that we announced through our national conference recently, with both the priority zones for schools that need the help and the abolition of the EBA, were the first two most important steps that we could see. Rather than the government scoffing at these things, what they need to do is to re-examine very carefully where they actually sit on these issues and to make sure that, at the end of the day, they are going to be able to face up to the outcome of their decisions. The outcome of their decisions will be read by this community at large and will be measured and judged in exactly the same way as this government is approaching them.

In conclusion, I oppose entirely the whole thrust of this government in relation to their education funding policy. I am appalled by the fact that they wish to drive such wedges through our community. We are going back in a debate that was finished many years ago. I would encourage them to consider very carefully the judgment of their actions in the future because, frankly, I do not know very many people out there at all in the general community who are going to applaud the outcome of this bill as it stands.

talk.start.para: —In March 1997 the Commonwealth, state and territory education ministers agreed to a national literacy goal, and that was that every child leaving primary school should be numerate and should be able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level. I draw the attention of the House to that as fundamentally a state problem. Both sides of the House would agree with that laudable objective that Australia's young children should have these skills when they leave the primary school level. The Commonwealth agreed at that conference to provide grants for fostering literacy and numeracy development, targeting the educationally disadvantaged students, and grants for national literacy and numeracy strategies and projects. So this government are committed to ensuring that Australia's young people in this modern age have the capacity and the ability to read and write at an advanced level for a western nation.

speech.para: I am concerned that the debate in this parliament has been divided quite strongly on this States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000 and, fundamentally, on the funding of independent schools. The real argument is the matter of Australian parents and their children having a choice about whether they wish to attend an independent school and pay the necessary funding or, on the other hand, wish to attend a government funded school with no payment from the parents involved. In my assessment, that is a fundamental right of Australian parents. I think those sitting opposite agree with the fundamental position that, no matter what state or territory Australian parents come from, they are entitled to make the choice of school that they wish for their children. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that this government has provided an alternative choice of private health care. Again, those opposite got involved in a major argument about the ability of private health funds to provide this choice and the cost to Australian taxpayers. We see a situation in both health and education in this society where people have a choice and where the system is not dominated by government agencies. That is very much in the ethos of the Australian tradition: we have a choice, we make those decisions and on some occasions we make a contribution to that choice.

In my home state of Victoria, 31 per cent or thereabouts of students attend independent schools. So parents of almost one-third of students have made the choice and are prepared to pay the money so that their children might attend an independent school which is funded partly by the federal and state taxation system and also partly funded by the after-tax dollars of the parents. The parents have a choice of curriculum and of the quality of that curriculum; the quality of the teachers; the class size, either small or great depending on the economics of the school; the discipline which the school may apply, either good, fair or not so good; the ethos of the school, which can vary from institution to institution, as most of you would be aware; the academic standards that the school will apply to their students and staff; and the performance outcomes of those students. That is very important, and the independent schools and, to a degree, the state schools are in a competitive situation to ensure that their students are beating those quality outcome standards. Of course, a number of independent schools have a religious background. It is fundamental in Australia that independent religious organisations have the capacity to create a school of their choice.

I would like to draw to the attention of the House in a calm and equitable manner—unlike some members opposite who have been a little bit excitable about this debate—what the shadow minister and others opposite have had to say about this debate. I agree with the shadow minister, the member for Dobell, when he says:

quote.para: Improving educational opportunities for every student at every school must be our goal.

speech.para: That is the goal of those of us on this side of the parliament. In another part of his speech yesterday, he went on to say:

quote.para: Raising the standard of education and training in Australia does not just open up new career choices for young people who are at risk of dropping out or disconnecting from our society and it does not just open up better career choices for students; it also opens up new possibilities for our country.

speech.para: We have no argument with that. We support the general philosophy. The shadow minister then talks about the situation in the United States where training of the teachers has shown a big improvement in recent times. I was fortunate enough to be in the United States in recent weeks. It was quite clear from the Governor of Florida, the brother of the candidate for the presidential elections, Jeb Bush, that training of teachers and their activities in schools in Florida were under considerable review. If a school did not get the desired outcome in year 1, they got more funding, in year 2 they got more funding if the schools were not up to standard; but in year 3 the parents of children at those schools have the right to take their children away. Even in America the standard of teachers is being looked at very carefully. I note that the second reading amendment moved by the shadow minister states:

quote.para: ... the distribution of funding among the non-government schools is profoundly unfair.

speech.para: I refute that statement quite categorically, as I will go on to demonstrate. The member for Rankin made a sensible contribution and had this to say:

quote.para: In fact, in my view, there is a lot of merit in the concept underlying the funding formula introduced in the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill because that funding formula is based on an index of socioeconomic status. But the application in this legislation of the SES funding formula is flawed.

speech.para: But he agrees with the basic concept and he has it on the record. At least he is applying it intelligently. I listened carefully to the contribution by the Leader of the Opposition. Again, that was a considered position. He has a long history in the education debate. Of course, his father introduced state aid during the time of the Whitlam government in 1973. I note that he is not opposed to funding going to independent schools. He has put on the record that he is not opposed to the funding.

talk.start.para: —Do you believe it?

—It is interesting whether or not we believe it, but he said in a carefully prepared statement to this House that funding to independent schools should be on a needs basis. That is where we have a little bit of a problem in how we apply the original state aid argument which Kim Beazley Sr introduced in that historic legislation in 1973. The really fundamental question facing this parliament and this nation is how we apply taxpayers' dollars to the independent school sector, whether it should be needs based or on the parental capacity to pay. This government and the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs have brought about a fundamental change, with which some members on the other side of the parliament agree, that we need to look at the capacity of parents to make a payment in the independent school sector rather than establishing that schools have a certain amount of wealth—and I say the word `wealth' advisedly.

speech.para: A number of members opposite have made great play about certain independent schools being wealthy, but they have not acknowledged that a number of the parents paying the fees to these so-called wealthy schools are of middle income means, who pay their taxes and who make great sacrifices to send their children to a so-called wealthy school. I concede the point that some of the schools in category 1 do have facilities that have been built up over decades by parental support and by the hard work of previous generations, but the real difficulty in applying funding to independent schools is how to identify which of the categories a school should be in. As all speakers in this debate would be aware, the categories range from category 1, regarded to be the wealthier schools, to category 12, regarded to be the schools with poor facilities and low parental income. Although it has been conceded on both sides of the debate that those two categories are self-evident, there are some anomalies in those areas. I draw to the attention of the House the great difficulty the administrators have in identifying which category certain schools might fit into—whether they should be in category 3, category 7 or category 8. The differences between those categories are brought about by some strange arithmetic calculations and historical data, which I think the administrators of the departments have great difficulty understanding themselves.

It is interesting to compare schools in my own electorate in the Geelong region. A school in category 10 has fees ranging from $1,600 to $1,800. In a category 1 school, the fees range from $6,000 to $10,000. The difference between the category 10 schools and the middle category schools—those between category 3 and category 6—is $3,500 to $7,500 depending on the category the administrators put those schools into.
