I have had considerable representations from schools in my area that this system is unfair and that arbitrary judgments by administrators, putting schools into particular categories, do not deliver reasonable outcomes for those parents. Those parents pay their taxes and they pay the school fees with after-tax income, yet by an arbitrary movement by the department here in Canberra, based on historical data, schools can end up in a category that I think all fair-minded people would question. So the minister and the government have come up with a new system and funding formula which we on this side of the parliament advocate is fairer to the parents. I think even the Leader of the Opposition would concede that the category system has some flaws. The opposition were unable to provide an alternative system when they were in government.

It is interesting to observe that, in the Australian system, parents provide about 45 per cent of the total funding for non-government schools. In rough terms, parents provide about half the funding to their private schools, the Commonwealth provides about 37 per cent and the states provide 18 per cent. In very round terms, the parents provide half the funding and the Commonwealth and the state, out of taxpayers' money, provide the rest.

In providing a new regime for independent schools, the coalition abolished Labor's new schools policy, a policy which fundamentally stopped the establishment of any new non-government schools. That allowed a genuinely competitive situation and gave choice to parents in rural, regional and urban Australia. If you talk to independent schools, they are bemused by the complex ERI—the education resources index—process and have difficulty understanding it. In many ways it is inequitable because schools serving the same community, as is the case in the Corangamite electorate, can be funded quite differently. Those figures I quoted a moment ago demonstrate that point. The ERI is inflexible because the schools tend to be locked into a funding category, and they are unable to move up or down depending on changes in circumstances.

The other key feature is that independent schools that make an effort to raise funds in a capital sense are discouraged because of their category. The proposition the government is putting forward, after considerable research, is the SES—the socioeconomic status of the school community. This transparent methodology was developed by Melbourne University, the data being available from the reliable census figures. The SES methodology is fair and is related to parents' capacity to pay. The SES methodology is flexible, so schools can move according to their background parental capacities. The SES methodology removes the disincentives to private investment and provides the private sector with the choice to raise more money to improve the possibilities of that school both in an educational and a capital sense. Surely in the interests of the whole of Australia that is a step in the right direction. The SES is a simple process.

For the interest of members—the process has not been debated in the parliament—the students' addresses, not the names of the students, are taken from the ABS collection and an index developed. Fundamentally, if the SES score is over 130, the school will receive the base entitlement they are now receiving. All schools with an SES score of 85 or below will receive maximum funding and those schools in between will get an ongoing entitlement, depending on where they sit in the program. The funding is based on the average government school recurrent costs. It is based on the government school arrangements where that is a genuine costing. Those opposite cannot really complain too much about that.

In the remaining minutes, I mention that it was interesting to receive two letters from proponents of, and those against, the arguments. The Australian Parents Council has written a letter to all members. I think they understand the argument that this bill recognises that every child is entitled to a base level of public funding. They say in the second dot point in their letter that the bill is based on `a more transparent measure of educational need', rather than on the old one to 12 situation. They say that funding relates to `Average Government School Recurrent Cost', something that I have mentioned, and that `this proportion ranges from 13.7 percent to 70 per cent of the government cost'—again, a fair and equitable system that everyone can understand. They further say that this bill `guarantees security of Commonwealth funding for non-government schools' in the new funding arrangements.

We also have a letter from the Australian Education Union. In all fairness, I looked at it very carefully to see whether it proposes a sensible argument against the proposition that the government has put forward. After viewing the letter, I really cannot see a sensible argument. They say `simply don't blame state governments' for any difficulties in the education system. Fundamentally, the state governments run the primary and secondary education system and we give some assistance to them by way of grants, but we assist the independent sector. So I do not think that the Australian Education Union really has a good argument.

I will just summarise the position as I see it in this very seminal and important debate on education in Australia: the new funding model is about parents, students and educational choice—matters I have raised before. It is not about government school versus non-government school, which so many members opposite have put in their arguments time after time. Every child in Australia is entitled to support from the government for their education, whether for a total amount or a smaller amount to independent schools. The new funding for non-government schools will not lead to a reduction in government school funding. The minister and the government have made it quite clear that they will increase the total amount of federal funding for schools in their area of responsibility. The new funding model uses objective data about the needs of school communities to redress the past inequities and to fund schools in similar circumstances in similar ways. That summarises the position quite simply.

Parents who invest their after tax savings in their children's education contribute to the national investment in education, and that is a desirable outcome. Parents using non-government schools in Victoria save Victorian taxpayers $650 million. That is a desirable outcome from the Victorian taxpayers' point of view. For every dollar of taxpayers' funds that state and federal governments spend on government schools, only 25 per cent is spent on non-government schools. That is a very important fundamental statistic that those opposite have tended to complicate and argue against. I strongly advocate the new system as being fair and reasonable. I hope those opposite will support the bill in the Senate, that the Democrats will support the bill and that there will be a new era of fairness and equity in independent schools funding. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to make a contribution to this debate on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. The Labor Party has a special interest in education. We see it as our future. The government sees education only in terms of another avenue to advantage their friends or advance the privatisation agenda. The Labor Party believes in equal opportunity. We do not believe privilege should decide whether you get a good education. We do not believe you should be able to buy education. What the government means by choice is not what everybody else means by choice. It is restricted to those with the ability to pay. I am concerned, representing an electorate that overwhelmingly uses the public school system, with the statement of intent by the minister that he is actively wanting a shift from the public school system to the private school system. That was recorded in the coalition ERC minutes of 1991. I will read from those minutes where it says:

quote.para: It was agreed that Dr Kemp would report back to the committee on non-government schools whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and in untied grants.

speech.para: Well, he has. And this is what we have today: the complete opposite of what the minister stated publicly on Meet the Press. It was raised by the shadow minister during question time last week. The minister's response was:

quote.para: Get real.

speech.para: The House will recall that he was invited by the Speaker to more adequately respond. He said that he had not completed his answer and again said:

quote.para: Get real.

speech.para: That was the extent of it. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs is telling the shadow minister for education that it is okay to say one thing in private and another in public. He did that in relation to universities when he said that the government had `no plans to charge commercial rates on university education'. What did he do? He put forward a nasty proposal to limit university education to paying students, paying $100,000. This is what the minister means when he says `get real'. We are real. We do not need to `get' it in that 1960s sense of the word. Where the minister is unreal is in expecting the public education system to provide a decent standard of education when it is being white-anted by incentives provided by the government for parents to exercise their so-called choice and send their children to privately run, fee charging schools. It is unreal to expect every family to be able to do that. That is the first point.

talk.start.para: —Where did you send your kids?

—I can see that I am upsetting the parliamentary secretary at the table. My children actually went to public schools. It is unreal for the public schools to be expected to deliver a reasonable standard of teaching when their school populations are reduced to those who have been kicked out of the private school sector and those from less well-off circumstances whose parents do not have any choice. That is the second point. It is unreal to believe that the EBA has any effect other than to reduce the capacity of the public school system to provide any sort of quality in education. They are turning into adolescent-minding centres so that the youth allowance can be paid to teenagers who really do not want to be there. They are being forced to time-serve with inadequately resourced teachers who do not have the time to help these young people to plan their vocational avenues, to sort them out and to guide them away from wasting their lives after they leave school.

speech.para: These students have to attend classes as if they have every intention of completing the higher school certificate. It leads to problems for other students who do have every intention of doing as well as they can at those difficult final exams. It takes teaching away from teachers. That is the most important point. This government is intent on making government schools fail. Exclusive schools are just that. They can exclude those students they do not want. They can dump the ones they do not want back into the public schools, and that includes the underachievers and those with limited literacy skills.

Public education is certainly a challenge. We have got laws that compel parents to send their kids to school. We talk about universal education and the minister talks about quality education, yet Commonwealth funding for government schools through the EBA has cut $60 million out of that system over the last three years. Principals and staff put their hearts into building a school, then another school opens up nearby. If it is a category 11 school, the public school may lose students. When the Commonwealth is actively bankrolling privately run schools in competition with public schools, planning for educational needs in the public system becomes very difficult. The minister sees this as market forces at work, offering choice to consumers. In fact, it is creating a chaotic situation where the outcomes are not predictable and the disadvantage is all on the public school side.

School councils are writing to me saying they are concerned about the decline in public education while private education appears to be advancing. They look to the resources they have and they compare them with the new buildings springing up as non-government and privately run schools, thanks to the Commonwealth government. What they are observing are the effects of the government's redirection of funding from government schools to a competitive, private model in the guise of choice. The government is privatising education by putting the crunch on public education. It is transferring the cost as quickly as possible with this legislation. Dr Kemp calls it reforming the government school system, but it is wrecking the government school system, and it will mean lower income families and disadvantaged families will be left to spiral downwards. Their kids will be in an educational desert, and the more disadvantaged the family, the greater the desert.

It happened in New Zealand in the name of choice, but it is really unregulated competition. We have the same before us. Disadvantaged kids were the losers there and the educational outcomes produced greater inequality. Maori communities were the hardest hit. If we adopt this sort of public squalor/private wealth muddle here, we are not going to break the cycle of generational disadvantage; we are going to entrench it.

The SES model is an attempt by this government to look after its landed constituency. We in the Labor Party believe in a needs based system. If you are on the land and you have a modest income, fine. If you are on the land with a good income but you are surrounded by people of modest income, this SES arrangement determines that you are poor. The government admits that this is so in the arrangements it has to make for remote Aboriginal settlements which are situated, say, near a major mining town. If you have the means, says the government, we will not stand in the way of a substantial donation to the school. This is very interesting. Richard Pratt's $1 million cheque last year to the minister's old school, Scotch College, should not affect how much the taxpayers put into Scotch College. It is only the school showing a bit of enterprise. The public schools should learn from places like Scotch College and their adulterous but generous benefactors.

The old system, the ERI arrangement, stood in the way of those sorts of donations. Non-government and private schools were, under the estimate, discouraged from getting out and doing a bit of good, old-fashioned fundraising. The government wants to get rid of the disincentives to private investment in education. Private and corporate sponsorship are uncapped. They want to transfer the cost of education away from the public sector and give non-government schools unlimited exercise over their expenditure—with almost double the Commonwealth assistance to the wealthiest private schools to help them along.

Social security payments are subject to an assets and income test—a means test. If you have the means, you do not qualify for government assistance. That is what the ERI measured: the means of those schools outside the government system seeking government assistance, and some of them sure had means. They had money and the full range of professional services—accountants and lawyers—to help them with their books. The best a poor public school P&C can come up with is willing hands and wonderful heart.

Knox Grammar can expect maybe an extra $1.3 million a year out of this legislation. Why is that? Why will the 62 top schools in the country get an additional $50 million a year out of this legislation? Why are taxpayers in my electorate being told they will have to pay for rich kids at elite schools with funds taken from their own basic and often deteriorating schools? And those elite schools will be free to increase their fees without any impact on the level of government support they get. The status of a private school is too frequently measured by the fees. This legislation will entrench fees over performance, facilities over excellence, class over equality, and new money over old money: the rich and tasteless.

Dr Kemp has a strange and pessimistic vision of the future. He wants to entrench and fortify privilege. Kim Beazley, on the other hand, sees the future as an exciting time, rich with opportunities; but only if we invest in education now, for everyone. Times have been changing over the past 20 or 30 years. Migrants are most likely to be the Australian citizens with a greater commitment to their obligations and responsibilities than those still looking to the Queen. Those who came to settle here have had kids, and some of those kids who were born here have had kids. Life has moved along. The more recent arrivals, particularly among those from South-East Asia, actually value education. Their children quite freely acknowledge that they are working hard at their studies because their parents put so much into their future. It is not true of everyone, but it is true enough when parents have had to flee death and danger.

Migrants do it tough here. They have to deal with the language barrier; they work hard to scrape the dough together and they live at the low cost end—all to give their children the full benefits of the opportunities they see. A lot of the children are bright, but the families do not have the resources to have them in private education. Whatever the so-called encouragement is, they simply do not have the money. They are people who have had a huge set-back. It is called `war'. Many had their studies interrupted before coming to Australia where they then had to take any job they could, learn the language, drive taxis, work night shifts, resume studies in English while dog-tired from work and, because time has moved on, start a family.

Australia used to harbour prejudices against Europeans because they worked hard. Con the fruit man would have his kids working for him too, and the milk bar would be open seven days a week. I am pleased to report the work ethic is alive and well in my electorate of Fowler. I wish 1 could say the same about access to migrant English classes. In the last budget, $20 million was pulled from the Advanced English for Migrants Program. Why do we want to have immigration if it is only to condemn immigrants to be the working poor because they lack English skills? We are overlooking people with talent and skills—people who can contribute to their adopted country. They are resources we cannot ignore. They are mothers and fathers of children who will make us the knowledge nation. We can all share in a bright and prosperous future.

I can see the potential every time one of my local schools comes to visit Canberra, which is less than a few hours bus time away. The electorate has people of many different backgrounds and the kids reflect that. I have not come across a teacher who has not said something very positive about their students. Research shows a strong relationship between school disadvantage and educational assessment. Fowler, in Sydney's south-west, does not score too well in the wealth stakes overall, but the teachers there think the kids are terrific because they are keen to learn—maybe it is to do with mum's and dad's attitude; it certainly is not to do with socioeconomic disadvantage. My electorate had three students awarded the Australian Students Prize last year for achieving higher school certificate results—a wonderful effort—in the top 500 nationally. Their parents came from Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam.

Education should not be about redistributing resources to the top end of society. Education should be where equal opportunity means something, not just for the students or their prospective incomes. Oh no, we need brains to seize the opportunities Kim Beazley sees ahead. And, in the most Aussie way, we should not care whether the student is the child of a shop owner living above a shop in downtown Cabramatta and attending Canley Heights High School or is a student at Abbotsleigh. We will take both of them. They are our future, so long as they do not go offshore because of the lousy level of research grants and postgraduate openings this government is offering.

There were scientists demonstrating outside Parliament House last week. They were not your average workers. These were brain workers. Dr Kemp should have gone out there and talked to them. If we are going to get the brightest people looking after our country's future, we need to focus on where they live. We need to lift those areas where they are starting from behind. We need priority education zones where bright kids get a chance to do something for the nation, instead of ending up unhappy, with an incomplete education and a job that does not exploit their full potential. It is a wicked waste that directly threatens our and their future and guarantees a return to the class system, the social unrest it promotes and the cost it takes to maintain it.

These are good reasons to resist this new formula. They are reasons of self-interest. I would have thought the government would be comfortable with self-interest as a philosophy, but this legislation takes self-interest in its narrowest meaning. Only the few, under this legislation, will be able to get their hands in the till, and they will not be grateful. To them, it is only okay to get a government handout if it is by devious accounting or avoidance of one's financial commitments to the revenue. To them, people who get the dole are a lower form of life. But there is no difference: tax avoidance is the same as dole fraud, except tax avoidance is the easier of the two. They are both rorts, and so is this legislation. The wealthy schools have welcomed the SES approach. The wealthy schools have seen the simulation figures. They have had them for the past two years and are in a good position to make the judgement that the SES makes the sound of money sweeter.

The department knows the figures. The minister knows the figures. The parliament does not know the figures. We are told we will see something some time this month, and here we are debating legislation in this House without knowing the full impact of the changes. No wonder this legislation has been mysteriously held up, delayed and concealed. It has been done without consultation with the New South Wales Department of Education and Training—which is a stakeholder, a very major stakeholder, because the department complements the funding provided by the Commonwealth to non-government schools and provides the public transport and other infrastructure for students whose parents are exercising choice in where they send their student son or daughter.

In the suburbs around Liverpool there is a great range of incomes. There are quite large houses in the estates often right beside extensive housing department developments. Getting a profile of one's family lifestyle by using census data for a collection district is an appalling misuse of statistical information. It is certainly not one I would use in campaign planning. The ABS warn against the sorts of assumptions you can make from the survey areas they can prepare for you, and most of that work is for commercial purposes—businesses looking at their markets.

There were a number of models considered in the schools funding consultation report. The SES model was just one of them. We on this side supported needs based funding, but the SES method looks like having some rough edges to it that the government does not want us to look at too closely. The enthusiasm of the wealthier schools leaves one to wonder if we are going to be spending this $22 billion of taxpayers' money wisely. As I said at the beginning, the Labor Party has a special commitment to education because the nature of work is changing. The government has not understood that, unless we set the goal of being a knowledge nation, we will be trashed by those economies that have embraced it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Education is the key to success both within Australia and on the world stage. It is the key that unlocks the door to knowledge, success, choice and a bright future. If as a nation we do not make a commitment to education and a commitment to quality education for all Australians—not just the few Australians that can afford to attend the exclusive private schools, the 62 category 1 schools many ministers and members of the government attended—then we as a nation are in real trouble. Education is something that is for everyone. Education is something that is a priority for a nation such as Australia.

speech.para: In Shortland, the electorate that I represent—in actual fact, in the whole of Newcastle—there is not one category 1 school. So how is this increase in funding of nearly $50 million to 62 schools relevant to the people that live in the Newcastle area? It is not very relevant at all. It shows just where this government's priorities stand.

This 1950s style government is led by a Prime Minister that sits in his Chesterfield chair, dreaming of the past and seeking to take Australia back to that era—an era where if your mother and father had an education, then you could aspire to a university education. But if your mother and father were ordinary blue-collar workers, working hard just to survive, then you were expected to follow them. The idea was that you had your place in life and that is where you stayed. If you were very lucky, then you could aspire to attend a technical college and maybe end up with a trade. But you must never, ever try to move out of your station in life. This is the vision that our Prime Minister, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the members on the other side of this House have for Australia.

This government has a distorted, outdated view of the world and the type of society we should live in. It is a view that is built on privilege and a belief that there should be a privileged class. The people that should form that privileged class are the government, the friends of the government and all the `right type' of people—those with money, those that have money now, those with education, those that have education now, those that have property, those that own great wealth and those in big business—and friends like Kerry Packer who gambles more money in one night than most people see in a lifetime.

This government supports and believes in a culture of privilege and elitism, and nowhere is this more visible than in education where this government demonstrates its philosophy. Nothing can be a greater determinant of wealth and opportunity in life than education. What this government is seeking to do through this SES model is to ensure that only those from a privileged background are able to obtain that education. Study after study has shown that a person's educational level determines their income level, which in turn determines their life opportunities and all the choices they have in life.

This government wants to keep that education in the hands of a very few people, those people that can afford to go to wealthy schools. This government has attacked the public education system in every way and has actually made an art of being able to attack public education. It sees the system as something to be applauded and pursued with a passion. That is the way the ideologues on the other side of the House see it. You only enter the public education system if you cannot afford anything better. It is not a real choice. We really should not do too much to support people who go to private schools.

Since the Howard government was elected in 1996, it has embarked on a 10-year campaign of undermining public education. There have been massive cuts to universities—$1 billion out of our universities. Research and development money to universities has gone. There are plans to charge $100,000 to do a degree. What ordinary Australian children coming from ordinary working-class families can afford to pay $100,000 for a degree? I certainly could not have afforded to do that. I could not have afforded to pay that for my children to go to university. What this does is really put university education in the hands of an elite few. There is talk about bringing in vouchers for education. The government wants to replace HECS with real interest rate loans. This is a disgrace. The government has slashed funds to TAFE; it has devised a plan to privatise education in Australia.

We know this is a government that believes in selling everything off. It has sold Telstra. It is pushing Australia down the privatisation road all the time. But surely you have to draw the line somewhere. Surely education is something that it is the role of government to provide. This government sees it as something that it brokers out to its friends in the private sector. Those that can afford it will get the quality education.

The Commonwealth funding is now being massively biased in favour of the wealthy schools—the schools that the members of this House who sit on the other side of this chamber went to. A majority of them went there. I find myself asking why any government would be so stupid as to jeopardise our future. I can only come up with one answer. That is that they are zealots. And the two head zealots are the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the Prime Minister, who are driven by an ideological obsession with the market. This government has pursued the privatisation of Australia's education system with zeal, and it is leading Australian society down the road to a future of lost opportunity and division, a society of haves and have-nots, where there are people living in absolute luxury, people that can have anything they want, whilst on the other hand there are people living from day to day, people that are having to approach charities for handouts, people that work hard and just cannot survive. This is a very sad picture in a country like Australia.

What this government is doing is entrenching the trends of the past where the children of professional parents were twice as likely as children of unskilled parents to go to university or even complete year 12. This is what it believes our society should be like—that it should be not your ability that determines what level of education you get but rather the family finances. I find myself looking at a number of decisions that are taken, particularly in education, and I feel as though it is a revival of the old feudal system. When I was at university, I looked at the natural order of things. It was put that there is God in the centre, then the nobles. I think that members on the other side of this House see themselves as the nobles. Then there is the middle class, who can aspire and have some money. Finally, you have got the workers. And the workers stay there; they must never look to change their position in life. I think the government sees us as ants and bees where you have the workers and the drones, and that is where they always stay. The queen is at the top. The government's vision of society is not of a modern, 21st century society. It is not an inclusive society. If it were an inclusive society, the government would understand that the wealth of the country should be shared by all. Education should be shared by all. Without sharing education, you cannot share wealth.

The ministers and our Prime Minister argue that by giving an extra $50 million a year to category 1 schools they are giving students and their parents choice. I ask the minister and the Prime Minister what choice they are giving a family that is struggling to put bread on the table. What choice will they have to go to, say, Scotch College, which has been given quite an airing here in the parliament? Where will they find the fees to pay for that? It is no choice. What the government is doing is taking money that would have been going into a school that they could actually afford to send their children to—the good local public school. What it is doing is taking money and resources away from those schools. What it is doing is ensuring that the public school down the road will not have a computer in it, will not have the same sporting equipment that the rich, category 1 private schools have. I find it absolutely despicable.

The bonanza the government has delivered to the category 1 schools may lead to a school like Melbourne's Wesley College reducing its $11,000 a year fees by $200. That will not benefit ordinary Australians and their children and it certainly will not benefit the people of Newcastle and Central Coast, the people that I represent here in this parliament. When we look at the members of the Howard ministry and where they went to school, we get some understanding of why they are giving category 1 private schools this extra $50 million. John Anderson went to the Kings School, Parramatta. The fees are $11,595. I know there are not too many families in Shortland that could afford that. Peter Costello went to Carey Baptist Grammar, Alexander Downer to Geelong Grammar, Robert Hill and David Kemp to Scotch College, Nick Minchin to Knox Grammar, Jocelyn Newman to Presbyterian Ladies College in Melbourne, Peter Reith to Brighton Grammar School, and Michael Wooldridge to Scotch College—Scotch College yet again!

Well, well, well! It is no wonder that we are here today giving extra money to those category 1 private schools. We are not about delivering quality education to all those kids that live in the south-west of Sydney, the west of Sydney, the Hunter; we are about making sure that those with money, those that come from a privileged background get the absolute, ultimate best!

We in the opposition support giving more funding to needy Catholic schools and independent schools. We are not opposed to that. But what we are really opposed to is the subsidising of wealthy schools, particularly when that subsidisation is at the expense of public schools, at the expense of ordinary Australian children. What it is doing is taking away their opportunity to gain an education. The government's SES does not take into account the resources that schools have either. I was absolutely disgusted when I read in the newspaper that donations and gifts to schools such as Richard Pratt's $1 million cheque to Scotch College last year will be ignored. The resources of the schools are totally ignored. These category 1 schools can get as many donations as they like, they can have as much money in the bank as they like, yet the government is still going to roll out this $50 million to the 62 most wealthy schools in Australia. I find that despicable, unacceptable and un-Australian. This government has a belief that it must redistribute wealth by taking it from those people in the most need and giving it to those in the least need. In other words, it thinks that those people that are poor and struggling or just making ends meet should take money from their pockets and give it to their wealthy friends.

With this legislation we see examples of how millionaires who live in rural areas will be classified as poor if the postcode fits. Most of us live in areas where there is a mix of income levels and some areas are wealthier than others. But if an area has a substantial amount of people that earn a low income then the wealthy people will still have the education of their children subsidised. It is just not good enough.

The Howard government's privatisation of our education system will have a devastating effect on the future of our children. This government is lowering the expectation of those Australian students whose parents cannot afford to send their children to school. This is really going back to the 1950s. I was talking to a young indigenous student recently who went along to a conference with other indigenous students. This indigenous student was horrified because she said, `Oh, when I finish year 12, I want to go to university,' and other indigenous students were saying, `Yes, I'd like to go to university too.' But the people that were in charge of this conference were saying, `Well, now, dear, maybe you shouldn't be thinking about going to university. Maybe you should look towards TAFE.' It is more of this stereotyping and putting people into little boxes. The little box areas—indigenous Australians, young Aboriginal people—should not be looking to university! Rather, if they are lucky, they may make it to technical college or TAFE!

This is a government of the 1950s, one that stereotypes all Australian students and Australians, one that has values reminiscent of the past and a destructive agenda, and one that robs students of opportunity. This is a government that is ensuring that only those with money have an education. It is elite. It has an elite approach to education and it wants to ensure that its friends are the elite of our society, that its friends are the ones that get to share the wealth. The Labor opposition do not accept this. We believe that all Australians should be given the opportunity to have a quality education. We believe that to deny bright young Australian students the opportunity to attend university is despicable.

The EBA should be abolished. We should restore funding to disabled students. Educational priority zones will be among things that the Labor Party will do, things that will really improve education in this country. The nations with educated, skilled work forces are the nations that will thrive. All Australians deserve a quality education. Your level of education should be determined by your ability, not your parents' income. If this government continues to privatise our education system, the system that 70 per cent of all Australian students attend, Australia will be the loser.

talk.start.para: —I have just been listening to the member for Shortland giving her perspective on the implications for her electorate of this States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. I would like to give my perspective on the implications of this bill for my electorate of Lowe. This bill has provoked quite a deal of controversy throughout Australia. The party I belong to, the Australian Labor Party, has opposed the material parts of this legislation, alongside sectors of the Australian polity—namely, the states, the Australian Democrats, the Australian Education Union and the Australian Council of State School Organisations. I note that the opposition to this bill has not been uniform, nor has it been unified. That being said, there are some common themes which I am compelled to raise tonight, issues going to the divisive nature of the legislation.

speech.para: Firstly, there is the issue of the balance of the financial allocation to schools. The allegation is made, with justification, that private schools get more and the state schools get less. The electorate of Lowe is truly a microcosm of the primary and secondary school system. Lowe has it all: we have a strong representation of category 1 private schools at both primary and secondary levels, we also have a very wide range of state schools which have a relatively strong asset and income means, and parts of the electorate have poor state and non-government schools. Lowe is a microcosm of Australian society. The bill we are discussing tonight is going to affect every corner of my electorate. It is of the highest importance therefore to accept that this bill will achieve winners and losers as a direct consequence of the changes being made. I have visited many schools in my electorate. I have seen one state school struggle for over 11 years just to obtain a new school hall. Another struggled to get proper funding to upgrade the children's toilet facilities. My electorate has some of the richest and some of the poorest schools in the state of New South Wales.

This bill provides major amendments to the existing State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996. Perhaps the most significant amendment in this bill is the abolition of the assessment method by the education resources index or ERI. The new system has an alternative method of funding called the socioeconomic status model, or SES, and is based on the socioeconomic status of school communities, as the Bills Digest notes, to `reflect the capacity of a school community to support its school'. The BillsDigest further defines the SES as an index calculated from Australian Bureau of Statistics data which links the students' home addresses with their ABS collection districts. A score is allocated for each school. The lower the SES score, the less likely that school will be able to support itself, hence the more money it will get. According to the calculations provided, no school funding is supposed to fall as a result of these changes. The highest scoring schools will still purportedly get a 1.7 per cent increase in funding whilst the lowest scoring schools will get an estimated 14 per cent increase from their current ERI level of funding. As for government schools, the government has committed itself to an increase in funding of $1 billion over the next quadrennium. In fact, this is a compounded total increase over the next four years.

Essentially, the proposals contained in this bill ensure that all non-government schools funding increases, but by differing amounts. The truth is that there are both government and non-government schools in my electorate which need funding, and this bill should afford welcome relief to those schools. Both are in need of real increases in funding. Both are looking to these amendments as a means of improving the funding of schools and achieving the standards of education we all wish to see in our communities. But let us not be duped by the complicity of this government to veil its proposed new system under a banner of equity in education. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs in his second reading speech at page 2 stated:

quote.para: Under the new arrangements general recurrent funding will be distributed according to the need and schools serving the neediest communities will receive the greatest financial support. This means that parents at all income levels will now have a realistic capacity to choose the most appropriate schooling of their child.

speech.para: What a comedy of errors in reasoning! We really need to dissect this statement and look at each mistake separately. First, the minister is asserting that the new arrangements will distribute the funds according to the need of schools serving the neediest communities. This premise is simply false. It is false because it is a fact that all non-government schools will enjoy an increase in funding. Under the new SES system, all non-government schools receive a minimum payment of 13.7 per cent of the average government school recurrent costs. By definition, not all non-government schools are schools `serving the neediest communities'. The conclusion is also false, but for different reasons. Simply, the minister cannot conclude that `parents at all income levels will now have a realistic capacity to choose the most appropriate schooling for their child'. If ever there were a case of an invalid conclusion based on a false premise, it is to be found here. The argument is wrong as well, basing the conclusion on a non-existent link with the premise. Put simply, what has the SES regime got to do with a parent's capacity to pay? Does the minister really believe that, by assessing a school's payments requirements under the new SES system, this will magically make any one non-government school more affordable for a battling parent? This is fictional nonsense.

It is true to say that these increases in SES funding will result in only modest decreases in school fees. Again, I note that some of the schools in my electorate are amongst the most prestigious and also the most expensive schools in Australia. By and large their fees are well beyond the economic means of all but the most privileged in Australia. The fee reductions from the new SES scheme are likely to be a drop in the ocean compared with the substantive gains that would need to be made to make such schools more affordable to the average parents' children. For working-class Australians, including single-mother families and those on minimum incomes, these amendments present no tangible improvement in choice of education. These people will simply have to take the nearest government school and be content with it.

I say all this with acknowledgment of the outstanding work of non-government schools in making arrangements for those who do not have the economic means to afford the considerable fees that are required to fund the infrastructures of these schools. Education, like anything else on this earth, is a case of `what you pay for is what you get'. I note the considerable efforts to which the wealthier schools go to make their schools affordable to those who would otherwise be economically excluded from such schools. I know of many individual schemes where these schools average out the fees, in effect using the fees structure to level out payments, ranging from payment schemes to a complete waiver of bills in some instances. By and large, the higher category schools simply out-price all but the most affluent. They have truly laudable policies designed to accommodate a wide cross-section of society so that all benefit from the infrastructure they have built over time. I firmly believe that such practices will continue in the future. It will not be the amendments contained in this bill that will achieve the social equity goals which the minister has glossed over as his justification for essentially giving more money to all non-government schools. It will be the selfless policies of the individual schools that seek to act in a truly charitable way in opening their doors to all people who would wish their children to be educated there.

The minister has confused the ultimate end of this bill with the instrument with which he seeks to achieve it. On the one hand he uses a new SES regime which effectively means more money to all schools. Yet the minister's stated reason for doing so is to afford greater access to choice of education. If the minister and this government were truly serious about access to the most appropriate schooling for children, they would accommodate the aspirations and needs of parents and their schools in their desire for policies which reflect the true doctrine of in loco parentis, meaning in the place of the parent. This means that a teacher is the parent for specific purposes. But this government, through its failure to ratify domestic legislation to better interpret the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, has in fact been a silent witness as states continue to ratify legislation which takes more and more power away from the parents.

I have watched with dismay the corrosion of parental rights in state and federal laws. This government has made great play of so-called parental rights and children's rights. Yet it is in the policy area of education that we have seen perhaps the greatest invasion of parental rights in this country. I speak of the amendments to various state and federal laws, too many to mention here tonight, which have essentially made it so difficult, I say near impossible, for parents' rights in supporting the needs of their children. I cite part of the Commonwealth Programmes for Schools Quadrennial Administrative Guidelines, approved by the minister, which is reproduced in full in the Bills Digest:

quote.para: A fundamental principle underlying the Commonwealth's role in school education is to support the right of parents to choose the educational environment which best suits the needs of their child, whether the school of their choice is in the government or non--government sector. Choice in schooling leads to diversity which, in turn, allows freedom of expression, accommodates diverse beliefs and values, stimulates innovation and promotes greater accountability for schooling outcomes to parents and to the wider Australian community.

speech.para: I bring this quote to the House's attention tonight because it is timely to remind ourselves of policies which this government is responsible for in the evolution of domestic laws which have had exactly the opposite intention. I speak of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child. This declaration is an international instrument which this government is a signatory to. It has been used to justify amendments to legislation directly relevant to the bill today. I speak of the group of acts that come under two broad headings, child protection and education reform acts. On this topic I can speak only of New South Wales, but I understand that similar legislation exists in other jurisdictions.

The use of the UN convention has been sold to the community to protect children. In fact, it has been used to deny parents the right to educate their children, especially in the use of corporal discipline. It is now perilous for a child to be chastised in any way. Any attempt to do so by a teacher is even more perilous. Government schools are universally compelled by law to implement non-corporal discipline codes that directly intervene on the natural choice of the parent in how their child should be disciplined. Non-government schools in New South Wales are now required to sign non-corporal discipline codes in fear of losing their registration status if they do not comply with the now infamous subsection 47(f) of the Education Act 1990 of New South Wales. In doing so, state and federal governments have ignored the broader body of criminal legislation which protects children against criminal offences. They have justified the existence of invasive new laws that trammel parents' rights in the name of children's rights, education reform and child protection legislation. A more correct terminology for these legislative aphorisms is `anti-parental rights'.

I bring these examples to the House's attention tonight to demonstrate the true direction of this present government in doing what it does best when difficult decisions are needed, that is, it either does nothing or flicks the problem to the states. It is the case with the proposed amendments to the in vitro fertilisation debacle and it is the same here with the education legislation. If this government were truly concerned about parental choice in education, it would enact legislation specifically guaranteeing the rights of the child and the rights of parents in separate legislation. Instead, it has sought to do nothing, leaving the states to make the difficult choices of how to implement such legislation. What has happened is that, in the case of New South Wales, state laws have had to contend with the onerous task of interpreting the UN convention by amending children's protection and education reform legislation, often with catastrophic results in terms of parental rights. Parental disciplining rights, a fundamental aspect of parenthood, have been trammelled simply because this government has not had the political will nor courage to define what that convention must mean in the context of domestic legislation. It was Chief Justice Mason, in the High Court decision of Teoh, who alerted the legislature yet again to the fact that UN conventions and other international instruments are not legislation. They are not drafted in the same style. Very often, it is necessary for domestic legislatures and jurisdictions to interpret such instruments to give them legislative effect so that there can be the proper implementation of the spirit of the legislation.

I am compelled to remind this House of the role of government in education. In particular, it appears necessary to explain to this government what its role in respect of education is. That is, government occupies a mediate role in education. The immediate role to educate has lain, does lie and always will lie in the hands of the parents. What this government is doing is reducing and ultimately eliminating the immediate role of parents to educate by redefining it. I note that the immediate role of parents to educate is a direct function of their unique procreative function. Their role to physically bring the child into this world is hand in glove with their educational and formative role with the child. Indeed, it is not until the child reaches the age of maturity that the role of the parent really ends—if the parental role can ever be said to end. It is for this reason that a parent has the natural powers over the child, including custody, guardianship, access and other powers. These facts are being progressively forgotten by this government. One has to go back to totalitarian regimes of nazism, fascism and communism to hear remarks about the state having a higher role and an immediate role that defeats the natural rights of parents to educate.

I say all this in the context of the minister's guidelines mentioned above. The truth is that this government is, by stealth, taking rights of parents away from their procreative power to educate their children. Fortunately, the public is awake to this trend. This is why there has been an explosion of parent controlled and independent controlled schools. This is why home schooling has also taken off strongly, and the public has risen to the occasion and demanded that such provisions have been imbedded in the various state and federal government instruments.

In New South Wales, we have seen the rapid growth of parents choosing to take their children out of both government and non--government systemic schools, precisely because there is no choice in the level and quality of the education of their children within these systems. It is for this reason that there is still choice in the education system as a whole. If left alone, this government would have further delimited choice in both curriculum and manner of education. Education is a holistic term that is more than the three Rs; it also includes the physical, disciplinary, moral and spiritual development of the child.

It is wrong and deceptive for the minister to describe the legislation in the way he has in his second reading speech. Yes, the funding is welcome for all non-government schools, but I am yet to be convinced that the distribution of income is fair for government schools. On this point I share my party's opposition to this bill in that it is unfair on government schools. However, the greater injustice is that the minister attempts to demonstrate that this bill is somehow fulfilling this government's obligation to parental and family rights, whereas in the broader context of laws and international instruments ratified by this government it has pandered to `one world government' initiatives to take away more power from parents by denying them real choice in how their children are to be educated, particularly with regard to their moral education. The conduct of this government is tantamount to saying, `You are free to educate your children so long as you teach them one type of morality.'

Where does this leave the minister's statement in his guidelines? I put to this House tonight that the conclusions reached in the Bills Digest are well founded: the bill does fall short in its financial allocation to the government school sector. Whilst this bill is primarily a finance bill, a darker message lies beneath the appropriations. That darker message lies at the heart of the issue of true parental choice in education. The gains made by parents in the state education systems have come at a price for those brave advocates who have fought the federal and state education bureaucracies to win the hard-fought rights of parents to educate. The minister can take no comfort from this appropriation to say that the existence of these rights is the doing of the government. Rather, it is testament to the mums and dads and the non-government and government school sectors that have fought long and hard for the concessions they have won.

Yet even this has not been enough. This government continues to take the rights of children to mean the rights of the state. This government continues to legally separate child from parent. This government continues to obfuscate the meaning of the terms `family' and `parent' so that it is increasingly difficult for parents to exercise any control over their children. This is due in large measure to the misapplication of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in domestic legislation which has torn families apart in the most culturally insensitive ways. It has lambasted families with specific legislation and denied parents any meaningful control over their children.

Finally, let me say that the minister has misrepresented the intention of this bill. This bill increases non-government school funding across the board. It apologises for this with a purported $1 billion grant over four years to the government school sector. However, let no-one be deceived: in real terms of affording choice to parents, the broader conduct of this government is to take further control over their children away from them and place further power in the hands of the government. That is clearly unacceptable. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to start by saying that I make these comments on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000 as a former teacher in the public school system, with a brother and sisters who have taught in the state system, but also as a parent who exercised choice in sending both boys to an independent school after their early public schooling. This is crucial legislation. It will lay the foundation, for better or worse, for federal involvement in school education at the beginning of the new millennium. It appropriates over $20 billion over the next four years for the purposes of school education. It deserves full and well-informed scrutiny by this place and by all members. It should not be voted for or against by anyone on the basis of party political rhetoric but should be voted on only after thorough analysis. After all, it deals with one of the most important areas, if not the most important area, that we as legislators can deal with—the futures of our children. Yet typically, like so many others that have preceded it, the debate on this bill takes place without the necessary information being put before members of this place. The bill was introduced to the House on 29 June and was immediately referred to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee. That committee was initially due to report back on 6 September but has now been granted an extension of time to report until 4 October. Once again this place is being asked to pass a crucial piece of legislation before part of this parliament's committee system has scrutinised the bill thoroughly and reported on it.

speech.para: I welcome the member for Fremantle to the front bench and say that I am pleased to see her in the chamber tonight. As she has said in recent times, such treatment of this place by the executive not only demeans it but makes it largely irrelevant in the democratic process. I congratulate the member for Fremantle for her recognition of the fundamental problems facing our democracy in terms of the manipulation of this place by the major political parties and the manipulation of those parties by big business and others with vested interests. I hope she retains that stance in her new position on the opposition front bench. But I say to her also that perhaps the best way to bring back meaningful debate to this place is either to get enough people on the crossbenches so that the government of the day cannot treat it with the contempt we have become so accustomed to or to be bold enough to recognise that proportional representation is the only fair way to achieve representative democracy. Only then will debate in this place take on real meaning.

The education resources index has been used since 1985 to calculate the relative levels of funding that non-government schools receive from the Commonwealth. It funds schools on the basis of their relative need by comparing the income the school is able to generate on its own behalf with a standard level of resource based on the cost of educating each student at a government school. As an indicator, it is therefore primarily concerned with the capacity of a school to raise funds on its own behalf. It has 12 different categories of funding, with category 1 schools receiving the least assistance. The most common criticism of the ERI—and I have seen it in my dealings with schools in Calare—is that schools servicing the same kinds of communities do not receive the same level of funding.

The Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs 1998 report on the SES simulation project cites the examples of Launceston and Canberra as two areas where schools serving largely the same communities receive widely different funding under the ERI. In Canberra's case, it has non-government schools funded in categories 2, 3, 6, 8, 10 and 11. The situation in Canberra is not dissimilar to that in Calare where, even after some recent reclassifications, schools servicing students drawn from largely the same communities receive different levels of funding. Another criticism of the ERI is that, by reducing government funding as private income rises, the scheme actually acts as a disincentive for non-government schools to seek greater private contributions. A further criticism is that the review process is not responsive enough and, in particular when a school seeks reclassification, as has happened recently to many schools because of the rural decline, the process is simply too bureaucratic and not transparent enough.

There is little doubt that the educational resources index as a method for calculating funding for non-government schools has passed its use-by date and requires either an overhaul or replacement. The question is whether the proposed SES model will provide a better way of funding non-government schools in terms of equity, certainty, simplicity and flexibility. The SES funding method will assess a school's need according to a measure of the socioeconomic status of the community or communities from which it draws its students. The SES is a statistical measure of the socioeconomic profile of a community. It is made up of a number of different aspects, including income, occupational status and educational status. Whereas the ERI aims to assess the capacity of a school to generate funds on its own behalf, the SES will assess a school's need by measuring the capacity of the community it draws from to support it. It works as follows. Students' home addresses will be collected, then linked into the Bureau of Statistics census collection districts data, which typically comprises about 250 households, and an SES index will then be applied to calculate the average SES score for each school community. Each school's SES score will then be calculated on the basis of the average SES of the communities from which its students are drawn and weighted according to the number of students from each census district at the school. The lower the SES score of a school community, the lower its capacity to support its school will be judged and the more government funding it will be entitled to. The SES method will return results in a way similar to how IQs are measured. An average school will return an SES score of 100. A school servicing a disadvantaged community will receive a score below 85. A school servicing our most affluent communities will return a score of 130.

So how does the SES system compare to the ERI? The simulation of the SES model conducted in 1998 by the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs covered 2,262 of the 2,519 non-government schools across Australia—not a bad sample. Given the thoroughness of that report, I have no reason to doubt the department's finding that the study was soundly based. The simulation returned SES scores ranging from 56 to 135. Schools with SESs at the lower end of the scale included those servicing communities with a large Aboriginal population and other schools servicing remote areas or certain metropolitan areas. Most of these were Catholic systemic schools. Schools returning scores at the other end of the scale were generally located in metropolitan areas well known for their high socioeconomic status. While the range of scores was high, of the 2,262 schools involved in the simulation well over half of them returned scores of between 105 and 90, 53 per cent of the schools scored below 100, while only 10 per cent of schools returned scores in excess of 115.

The simulation project's report went on to compare the SES measurements against the then current ERI categories. It found that, while under the ERI 76 per cent of schools were in the neediest funding categories, under the SES model there was a greater concentration in the middle ranges. The comparison shows that many schools assessed as needy or not needy under the ERI were similarly assessed under the SES simulation. The largest number of schools with SES scores above 115 were found in ERI category 1. The largest number of schools with SES scores below 85 were found in ERI categories 11 and 12. The problem appears to be in the middle, in ERI categories 6 to 10, where the SES modelling found relatively little difference between the communities being serviced but, under the ERI, the schools were receiving substantially different funding.

It is important to note that, for each of the ERI categories, SES scores were returned across a large range. For example, ERI category 2 schools returned scores ranging from 100 to 135—that is, from average to very affluent. Category 3 schools returned SES scores ranging from 90 to 130—that is, from a fair way below average to very affluent. Category 6 through 11 schools returned very similar SES scores, ranging from 90 to 120. For a comparison of these two systems, it is again interesting to look at the results from the Canberra region. The 35 non-government schools receiving ERI funding that participated in the study, ranging from categories 2 through to 11, all returned SES scores above the average, in the range 110 to126. These results suggest that some of those schools were receiving a larger than fair share of public funding on the basis of the relative capacity of the communities from which they drew support.

The government has made much of the broad support that the non-government sector has given the proposed SES model. But, as the simulation project shows, if the SES results were to be applied literally, many schools would have their funding altered substantially. Those that would have had their funding reduced would no doubt have objected to it. So it is important to note that, when the government says it has widespread support in the non-government sector, it is actually because all schools have been promised that they will be no worse off under these changes. The widespread support for the change in the non-government system is perhaps also due to the fact that the SES system will not apply to Catholic schools, not in this quadrennium anyway. It will not apply because, shortly before the results of the simulation report were released in December 1998, the government promised to ensure that the Catholic system received category 11 funding for all of its schools.

I recognise the political difficulties involved in putting in place measures which might reduce funding to some schools. However, given that under the proposed scheme private income earned by all schools will be disregarded, one wonders whether all non--government schools can reasonably expect to get increased funding as well as having open slather on raising other income. One of the valid criticisms of the SES funding system is that, while students attending a school might live in an area with a low socioeconomic status score, they themselves come from a family with a high socio-economic background. For example, if you take the Kings School in Sydney, which draws many students from regional areas, one might expect it to receive a relatively low SES score. Yet it could be argued that it draws from the most affluent families in those low SES regional areas. This criticism strikes at the core of the validity of the SES system as a mechanism for measuring a school's need. While the simulation report stresses that the SES was never intended to measure an individual household's wealth, one wonders how fair a system which does not do that at all can be.

I suggest such a result is unfair and wonder whether some second-tier test is required, perhaps looking at the number of students from a school with an SES below 85 who are in receipt of the youth allowance. The youth allowance means test now gives an accurate picture of individual family's incomes and the figures should be readily available to the department. A school returning an SES of under 85 but with few students on youth allowance would then be subjected to a second level of assessment. I hope the Senate committee looks at ways of amending the bill to ensure that this unfair aspect of the proposed change is removed.

The other area of concern I hope the committee will give close consideration to is the proposal under the SES scheme to ignore altogether a school's capacity to earn private income. It strikes me that such an arrangement keeps the playing field in somewhat of a level state but then issues spikes to the students from the more affluent school communities, thus increasing the gap at an accelerating rate between the richer schools and those below average, not to mention the gap between those affluent schools and the public sector. At this stage, I cannot see how this treatment can be justified for the most affluent schools with their greater capacity to raise funds.

In recent times, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has made much of the record levels of funding the government is providing to government schools. He has indeed claimed that over the next four years his government will spend almost a billion dollars more on public schools than has been spent in the previous four years. The true story is not in the dollar amounts but in the percentage of Commonwealth education payments going to each sector. In 1996, 2,221,557 or 71 per cent of students attended Australian government schools while the other 29 per cent, a little over 900,000, attended non-government schools. That year, 41½ per cent of total specific purpose education payments went to the government sector, while the other 58½ per cent went to non-government schools. That equated to Commonwealth funding of $606 per government student and $2,107 per non-government student.

By 1999, the number of students in government schools had increased to 2.247 million and in non-government schools to a little over 978,000—70 per cent and 30 per cent respectively. In 1999 compared to 1996, each student in the government sector was being funded an extra $103, representing a 17 per cent increase, while each student in the non-government sector was receiving $495, an extra 23½ per cent. According to forward estimates by the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, by 2003, each student in the government system will receive $792 from the Commonwealth, while each student in the non-government sector will receive $3,314. That will represent a 30.7 per cent increase per student for the government sector and a 52½ per cent increase per student for the non-government sector. These funding shifts appear to be outpacing the slight drift in students from government to non-government schools over the past three years, which is used as justification for these increases.

Part of the problem with this area of policy is the difficulty in pinning down exactly what is happening with funding. Like the health system, the fact that there is no clear responsibility between state and federal governments for school education makes it hard to know who to believe. It is not as simple as the member for Corangamite would have it—a matter of choice. While those with the means can choose their school, state schools cannot benefit from the affluence of their suburb or town except in a very marginal way. When you look at the figures, it is fair to say that, while funding for both sectors may be increasing, funding for the private sector is increasing by more not only in dollar terms but also in percentage terms.

Given that the proposed socioeconomic status assessment system will not apply to systemic schools, given the commitment that no non-government school will be worse off under the SES system and given that even the most affluent non-government schools will receive a funding boost and be free to earn private income as they wish without it having any impact on their public funding, it seems fair to draw the conclusion that, from the federal perspective at least, the SES method is likely to further widen the comparative federal funding gap between government and non--government schools.

I noted with interest the member for Parramatta's comments last night that parents of students from non-government schools pay taxes which provide revenue to a public education system their children will never access. The implication was that, because they pay taxes, they deserve to get some of that back to help their own children. I do not agree with that argument in all cases. People pay taxes for a whole range of reasons, whether it is for aged pensions, Newstart, Austudy, drug rehabilitation, research, the health system or, dare I say, to support politicians in their retirement. People pay taxes for all of these services which they might never themselves access. One of the most fundamental purposes of paying taxes, as far as I am concerned, is to provide as good an education as we can to all Australians, regardless of their means.

As I argued in my speeches on the aged care reforms, I do not care if people want to pay $100,000 bonds to enter a five-star Moran nursing home in an affluent area, but I want to ensure we have at least a three-star service across the rest of the sector. The same applies to education. Our available resources should first be directed at supporting the quality of a basic education. I doubt anyone can say the public sector with its class sizes and social and economic disadvantages is anywhere near three-star across the board. That, in essence, is the difficulty I have with this bill. At least to the degree that funding increases do not match cross-over to the independent sector, it appears to misdirect scarce public resources. I fought hard, and with success, for equity for transitional emergency funding between independent schools in my own electorate. I know they are generous in the scholarships they offer to the less well off, but my larger duty is to seek equity across the total education field, in all sectors. To the extent I have outlined, I think there are major flaws in the states grants formula. So, with the serious reservations that I have outlined and without knowing the results of the Senate inquiry, I am reluctant to support the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill as it stands at this stage. I expect substantial amendments that will address some of the problem areas I have identified before this bill returns to the House, and then let the minister argue why those amendments should not be made.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. The oldest and most poisonous issue in our nation's politics is state aid. One of the proudest achievements of the Australian Labor Party is its resolution of this issue in the 1970s. Through the establishment of the Schools Commission in 1973, the Whitlam government gave full and fair funding to the non-government sector. It established the principle of needs based funding. All schools, whether public or private, religious or non-sectarian, in the city or the country, were to be judged and funded on the basis of need. This bill is a perversion of this great principle. It reopens the bitter wounds of state aid and sectarianism in our society. It delivers a special deal to the Catholic school system—a deal which cannot be justified in terms of either education equity or public administration.

speech.para: While other parts of the non-government sector are to be funded on a school by school basis according to the new SES formula, the Catholic system will maintain its block grants, to be administered and distributed centrally by the Catholic Education Commission in each state and territory. Uniquely in the sector, the 1,700 Catholic schools in Australia will remain with the old ERI funding system. I cannot support this special deal. In terms of education policy, there is no reason why the Catholic schools should have funding rules different from the rest of the non-government sector. The resolution of the state aid controversy was supposed to deliver Catholic schools a fair deal, not a special deal. Special deals are antipathetic to the whole principle of needs based funding for our schools. In this instance, the government is applying a weaker standard of transparency and public accountability to the Catholic system than to the remainder of the non-government sector. While the Anglican, independent and Christian schools will have their funding distributed on a publicly accountable school by school basis, the Catholic schools will receive a block grant. Taxpayers will not know how this money is distributed and used.

As the Senate committee examining this bill discovered two weeks ago, the federal department does not ask for the detail of Catholic school funding. That was the admission—that the federal department does not ask for the detail of Catholic school funding. It is a disgraceful situation to have two different standards for the use of public money in the non-government school sector. It may even be in breach of Australia's antidiscrimination laws. Why should a Catholic school be treated differently from an Anglican school or a Muslim school or an independent school? Religious discrimination is one of the most sickening practices in any society, yet our national government is enshrining it in legislation. Not even government MPs can explain away this double standard.

In the past I have had cause to support the member for Parramatta in his campaign to apply rigour and discipline to government outlays in rural Australia. The member for Parramatta has declared himself to be an opponent of special deals and pork-barrelling. Speaking on this bill last night, however, these standards deserted him. This is how he explained the government's decision to devise special rules for the Catholic schools:

motion.para: That request was acceded to by the minister on the commonsense grounds that it would provide them with exactly what they requested ...

speech.para: Let me repeat that for the benefit of the House:

motion.para: That request was acceded to by the minister on the commonsense grounds that it would provide them with exactly what they requested ...
