speech.para: This is the commonsense on schools funding, Liberal style. It reminds me of the old drinking song, `We're here because we're here because we're here because we're here.' This is a scam of the first order. I am sure many members will be wondering how the parliament could have arrived at this position.

Let me provide some insights from my time as shadow minister for education. Prior to the October 1998 election, the Catholic Education Commission tried to engage both sides of politics in a bidding war for Catholic school funding. On the government side, the negotiations appeared quite complex indeed. On 13 August 1998, the coalition parties announced their new taxation package, including the introduction of a goods and services tax. Shortly afterwards, the Australian Financial Review reported that government MPs had met with a number of bishops. One of these gatherings, organised by the member for Lindsay, involved 20 MPs, two archbishops and three bishops. If it was not so serious, you would think it was an Irish joke. I understand that issues such as the GST, native title and education funding were on the table for negotiation and, in some cases, intimidation. One bishop reported in the newspaper that a senior Liberal had threatened to attack the Catholic Church with paedophilia allegations.

This shameful campaign seems to have been successful. During the 1993 election campaign, the Catholic Church, led by its Social Welfare Commission, opposed the inequities of the GST. One might have expected the same thing to happen in 1998. On 21 August, however, eight days after the policy's launch, the Archbishop of Melbourne, George Pell, announced:

quote.para: ... the tax package is a serious attempt to address the problems of an ailing tax system. There is no one Catholic position on an issue as complex as taxation. Tax reform is needed, the (current) system is inequitable.

speech.para: The Prime Minister, of course, has been quoting the archbishop ever since. Indeed, on 20 September 1998, Mr Howard announced the government's decision to move the Catholic system into the category 11 funding band, thereby committing the Commonwealth to an additional $100 million per annum. The departmental documents assessing the need for such a recategorisation have never been publicly released. As the ALP spokesman at the time, I wanted to match this funding quantum but not necessarily tie it to the Catholic schools. The $100 million per annum should have been available to all schools. Its distribution should have been determined by a thorough needs based assessment. Unfortunately this position was not reflected in our policy documents. After the election, I did not recontest my position on the front bench. To borrow the words of Luther:

quote.para: Here I stand; I could do no other.

speech.para: I remain opposed to special funding deals in education. They undermine the fundamental principle of needs based funding. They cause rivalries and resentment between sectors and between systems. They pit schools against each other, not on the basis of need but according to their political muscle and clout. They allow the powerful to prosper and the weak to be marginalised. They allow politicians to be corrupted and decision making to be perverted. Worst of all, in terms of schools policy, they undermine the historic settlement of the state aid debate. The minister for education, Dr Kemp, has embarked on a dangerous divide and rule agenda for the funding of Australia's schools. His special deal with the Catholic system reflects his determination to play politics with the education of young Australians.

This is one of the sickest things I have seen in federal politics, and the Catholic system has been ill advised indeed to play along. They are destroying the credibility of their own funding system. They are undermining the very basis of state aid: the fair and full funding of non-government schools. They are fouling their own nest. Ultimately, however, it is not the members of the Catholic Education Commission who will suffer most; the real victims will be the children attending Catholic schools. Not only is this deal wrong in terms of education policy and process, it sells short the funding needs of Catholic schools. Sadly for these schools, the backroom deal has backfired. The federal department has now advised members that, if the Catholics had joined the new SES system, they would have received an extra $240 million per annum—$140 million more than the amount they settled on. The parents of children in Catholic schools should be screaming blue murder about this injustice. The Catholic Education Commission was desperate to maintain its centralised control of school funding rather than move to a publicly accountable, school by school system. As Rev. Tom Doyle told the Senate committee on 22 August:

quote.para: The Catholic systems would have actually benefited more from an aggregation according to SES levels but in fact we opted, in negotiation with the government, to stay at level 11 in order to preserve the systemic nature of funding for Catholic schools.

speech.para: What a remarkable admission. Doyle is willing to receive less federal funding, less support for Catholic schools, on the basis that he maintains control of the distribution. Imagine the outcry if members in this place said they were willing to accept less money for schools in their electorates in return for having control of the funds. Imagine the outcry if the second biggest school system in Australia, the New South Wales government schools, wilfully and deliberately missed out on $140 million of federal funding. There would be calls for the New South Wales education minister and departmental head to resign. Why should a different standard of performance apply to the Catholic Education Commission?

Rev. Doyle is also operating on a false premise: school by school SES funding would not threaten the systemic nature of Catholic schools. In every respect the system would remain in place. Its employment of teachers, its organisation of teaching materials, its framing of the curriculum and its testing and assessment of students—its core work would be unaffected by this change. The only change would be in the funding methodology: the distribution of public money would be determined by a nationally consistent and equitable formula rather than by Rev. Doyle and his colleagues at the commission. As government members are keen to point out, Rev. Doyle has actually praised the new SES system as being fair and open to scrutiny. This begs the question, of course: if the new system is so good, why isn't the Catholic Education Commission joining up? Why has it refused to join? I suspect that Rev. Doyle wants other publicly funded schools to be open to scrutiny but not his own. Perhaps he takes his inspiration from St Augustine, who said, `Lord, make me chaste and continent, but not just yet.'

I appeal directly to Catholic parents to right this wrong. I say to them: your education commission has let down you and your children. They have robbed your schools of $140 million each year for no other purpose than keeping power and control in their own hands. You should demand that your schools join the SES system and receive their rightful amount of federal funding. This is not only a debate about due process and accountability. There is strong evidence, especially in New South Wales and Queensland, that the Catholic education commissions do not distribute their public funding equitably. For a number of years, parish priests covering my electorate have complained about the underfunding of their schools. Funds are distributed on a per capita basis to each diocese. Redistribution takes place only within each district. Obviously this disadvantages schools in western and south-western Sydney compared with the North Shore. It is unacceptable for taxpayers to contribute $2 billion dollars annually to Catholic schools without any guarantee of its equitable distribution.

This is not a standard the parliament applies to any other area of public expenditure. Imagine the outcry if the Aboriginal affairs minister could not detail the allocation of funds in his portfolio. Imagine the controversy if the education minister could not report to the parliament on the funding received by each Australian university. Why should the Catholic Education Commission be exempt from proper standards of public accountability, transparency and distribution? As long as the Catholic system operates under a special deal, the situation can only get worse. At the Senate committee, Mrs Temby from the Commission was asked about the prospects of Catholic schools at the end of the current funding period. She replied as follows:

quote.para: At the end of the quadrennium it will be another discussion.

speech.para: Another discussion with the government—that is, another opportunity for cutting a deal, another opportunity for a bidding war between the major parties. For those of us who want state aid to work, this is an absolute tragedy. The funding of non-government schools was never supposed to end up this way. State aid was not supposed to be a system in which a particular church throws its weight around and negotiates a special deal with the government. In some respects we have created a monster. The political system is unwilling to say no to the Catholic Education Commission. It has become one of the untouchables of Australian politics.

I am sure some MPs will be a little startled by my approach in this debate. They probably see politics as an exercise in coalition building—strapping one interest group onto another and hoping to form an electoral majority. They probably assume that the Catholic Church wields substantial electoral clout, placing it beyond challenge in a two-party system. I believe that these assumptions perpetuate the myths of the old politics. The information age is driving a new politics—one characterised by the flattening of hierarchies and the dispersal of information. New technologies are wiping out the middle person and are empowering the individual. In a better educated and skilled society, people are wanting to make more of their own judgments and to take more control of their own interests and entitlements. They have less respect and less time for large hierarchical organisations. They want power to be dispersed to the many, not concentrated in the hands of the unaccountable few.

The Catholic Church is, in general, a victim of these trends. It is losing popular faith and public support. The Catholic Education Commission in particular is an example of a flawed and authoritarian hierarchy. In the new politics, I believe it is a paper tiger—trying to bluff the political system and hang on to its concentrated power and funding. This is the classic case of an insider trying to exercise power at the expense of outsiders—the parents, students and teachers who, under the present system, have no say in the allocation of Catholic school funding. This parliament should not protect the rights of insiders; it should enfranchise the participation of outsiders. We should appeal directly to the parish schools and expose the disadvantage they are suffering under the Catholic Education Commission. We should highlight the authoritarianism of the commission and the gross inequities of its actions. Moreover, we should condemn this government as a government of special deals—deals to buy off rural industries, deals on digital TV, and now the perversion of school funding for the non-government sector.

I am absolutely certain that the parents and teachers in the Catholic system will respond positively to this approach. They want their public representatives to stand up for a fair deal, not for the entrenched interests of an education hierarchy. These parents and teachers cannot afford to miss out on $140 million in funding—the equivalent of a seven per cent funding cut. Imagine the outcry if some other set of schools was losing seven per cent of their potential funding. That is what the Catholic Education Commission has inflicted upon themselves. It is an absolute scam. These parents and teachers cannot afford to give their children anything but the very best start in life. In short, they cannot afford this government's special deals. The parliament should have just one priority in schools funding: the needs of students. This should not be about party politics or the interests of education administrators, and it should not be about political power or backroom deals.

I feel sick in the stomach, quite frankly, to know that parish schools in my electorate are going to miss out because of this deal and that they are going to be short-changed in this fashion. They are needy schools. I am a supporter of state aid. I want those schools to get a better deal, to receive more funding, to provide a better education for working-class communities in my electorate. How am I supposed to feel knowing that their commission has done them out of seven per cent of their funding? It is an outrage, and I will be communicating that directly to every school and every parent in the Catholic system that I can find in my constituency.

I feel saddened to know that this bill undermines the principles of state aid and, in the absolute madness of Dr Kemp, is likely to reopen this terrible debate. I urge the Catholic Education Commission to reconsider the folly of its approach. It is fouling its own nest. It needs to rethink the deal it has formulated with this government. It needs to reconsider the folly of what it has done. This is not a happy occasion for schools funding. This is not a proper bill for the non-government sector. This, I believe, takes the education funding debate in this country back several decades to when non-government schools were not treated fairly, were not treated on the basis of need, and were not given a fair deal by the federal government of their day.

For this government to play politics, to manipulate and to cut special deals, all for crass electoral advantage—or what they thought was electoral advantage—is one of the lowest moments in the history of this House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: —I listened with interest to the remarks of the member for Werriwa on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. Whilst I am not sure that I agree with everything he said, I think there is a great deal of substance in the general message he gave. I was particularly attracted by the view that what we should be doing in this parliament is providing resources based on the needs of students. I say that in the context of this legislation. I make reference to the Bills Digest and take a moment of the House's time to read two paragraphs from it. It says:

quote.para: The Bill continues to implement the Government's policy in schooling aimed at giving families `greater choice in selecting which school best meets their children's needs'. The Government's choice and equity policy was first implemented in the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996. Firstly by the abolition of the New Schools Policy which lifted restrictions on the number of new non-government schools; and secondly by the introduction of the Enrolment Benchmark Adjustment (EBA) scheme which changed the formula for funding to government schools. These initiatives are widely interpreted as Government support of the non-government sector at the expense of government schools.

speech.para: Hear, hear! The bill implements a number of decisions made in the 1999-2000 budget, and they are outlined in the Bills Digest. It refers particularly to the socioeconomic status based model, and it says that it is debatable how effectively the SES model will achieve its objectives of supposedly serving the needs of the neediest schools in the community. It says further:

quote.para: Evidence presented to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee suggests that wealthier non-government schools will receive higher funding than poorer schools, including Catholic systemic schools—

speech.para: about which my colleague the member for Werriwa spoke. It continues:

quote.para: Catholic systemic schools will not be funded by an SES rating but will have a system funding level which preserves their year 2000 funding categories. Such an agreement honours the Government's 1998 election commitment to the Catholic systems.

speech.para: I was not privy to the deal about which my colleague spoke, but I would say that he raises some very significant questions about the level of funding going to needy Catholic schools in the private school system.
I want to make an observation about remarks made on this legislation by Ian Morgan. In an article in the Age on Wednesday, 30 August, Morgan writes:

quote.para: Dr Kemp has attempted to defend these measures as equity measures.

speech.para: This is a reference to the content of the bill. The article continues:

quote.para: But well over 80 per cent of the students from the major equity target groups—students from low socioeconomic status families, students of indigenous origin, students from rural and remote areas, and students with disabilities—are enrolled in government schools. The new bill directs money preferentially to the non-government sector, which under-enrols these students.

The real agenda is `competition and choice', code words for an agenda of markets in schooling, increased privatisation of provision, and increased privatisation of costs. The flaw in educational markets is obvious. They allow the already advantaged through wealth and influence to increase their advantages at the expense of the disadvantaged.

speech.para: And I say: hear, hear! I might point out that, in the case of the Northern Territory, we are, without doubt, statistically the most disadvantaged of all Australians in relation to this bill because the highest proportion of our students are in government schools. In 1999, 77.5 per cent of the 36,000-plus students were in government schools, against a national average of 69.7 per cent. This figure is the highest of any state or territory—the next highest being Tasmania at 75.1 per cent. That rings alarm bells for me. I analyse the performance results of students in the schools and I look at the benchmark used in this place and elsewhere in the community for year 12 retention rates. In 1999, the Northern Territory had the lowest year 12 retention rates at 48.2 per cent for male students and 57.8 per cent for females, which were against a national average of 68.4 per cent for males and 79.5 per cent for females—the Northern Territory was 20 percentage points less in performance for both males and females. Of course, if you look in more detail at those figures, you discover that in the case of the split between indigenous and non-indigenous students, the figures are even more dramatic. I have figures for 1997—because I do not have the figures for 1999—and they indicate that the retention rate for indigenous students in year 12 in the Northern Territory was 9.4 per cent against 54.5 per cent for non-indigenous students. I think that there would not be a person in this House who would not believe that those figures are damning—and they are. We are seeing here an approach to funding of schools which will provide the richest families and the richest schools in Australia with pocketfuls of money out of the public purse, the purpose of which we are not sure of but it is supposed to provide some sort of equity.

I note in a press release from the shadow education minister that in fact the disparities are very obvious. What I am concerned about, not least of which is the argument presented by my friend the member for Werriwa, is the impact that this will have on the community. I have lived and worked in Northern Australia for 25 years. For some of that time I was a schoolteacher. I have been chair of a school council. Three of my children attend public schools and another of my children attends a private school. All the private schools in the Northern Territory, bar one, are categories 10 and 12 schools, so they are at the bottom end of the spectrum. They are unlikely to benefit from this legislation to the same degree as Carey Grammar or other great private schools. What is of concern to me is that we are not going to get the outcomes that we require for public education and the bulk of our community's students by moving money out of the public education system directly into the private education system—as is being done here through this legislation.

We hear in this place a lot about practical reconciliation. These are, in my view, government weasel words that somehow try to elevate the fact that they are barely carrying out their basic responsibility to all citizens to the level of special measures for indigenous Australians. In the Northern Territory, the government does not even bother with this subterfuge. It has a continuing history of shifting funds away from the most disadvantaged sector—remote area Aboriginal schools—and propping up urban schools in Darwin, Katherine and Tennant Creek. That could be justified if, in fact, you thought the funds were coming from another source to those schools in the bush. We need to understand that, if you move outside the spine of the Stuart Highway, away from the major mining towns, there are no high schools in any of the Aboriginal communities out there—and we wonder why the educational outcomes for indigenous students are as they are. We know that the public schools in remote communities in the Northern Territory do not have anything near the equivalent degree or quality of resources that their urban counterparts have, let alone as compared to Carey Grammar or Kings School in Parramatta or Geelong Grammar. Each of those schools will get something around $800,000 out of this exercise. The poor bush schools will get $4,000 apiece. I say that that is neither fair nor equitable, but most of all it goes well beyond the criteria elucidated by my friend the member for Werriwa on the allocation of funds on the basis of need. It is very clear that if we are to improve the educational outcomes for indigenous and other Australians who live in remote communities and in the bush we need to dedicate substantially more resources to them. I fear that this is not going to happen whilst we have this government in office.

What we know in the Northern Territory is that they have been cutting funds to government schools. The current minister for education in the Northern Territory could be more aptly described as the `minister for slash and burn'. He is holding back 20 per cent of school budgets and he has left 50 school teacher vacancies unfilled. In one area of north-east Arnhem Land they are 27 teachers short.

We need to understand that we are not now talking about Carey Grammar School or Geelong Grammar School; we are talking about remote bush schools where there are not only shortages of teacher resources but also shortages of capital. We do not have high schools. There is a shortage of infrastructure. The sorts of outcomes that we would want these children to achieve are simply not possible because the resources are just not available. Yet we have the Northern Territory government on the one hand, and now the federal government on the other, effectively denying them access to the resources that the taxpayer makes available to us in the form of revenue to this government and to the governments generally for the purpose of public education. What we are doing instead is shifting bucket loads of this money into the pockets of the wealthier schools in Australia.

I noted with interest the comments made by Justice Vincent from Victoria which were read out today in the parliament by the shadow minister for education. I will not repeat them here. What we also need to know is that, if we want to get effective educational outcomes in these remote community schools, we need to provide teachers with the resources that they require. And part of those resources is that they also require are decent living conditions, decent housing. We know that absolutely no effort has been made by this government or by the Northern Territory government to provide them with appropriate housing, so that many teachers live in demountables. They live in demountables, which I am sure you and I would not care to live in, Mr Deputy Speaker, and which would be regarded as a health hazard if they were in a major urban community. You certainly would not see them on the grounds of Carey Grammar. What we know about these places is that the roofs leak, the plumbing and the wiring breaks down, and people's furniture and other belongings get covered in mould. This does not happen at Carey Grammar. The contrast could not be starker.

I feel for the students in these communities, because they aspire to decent educational outcomes. Their parents aspire to decent educational outcomes. Most of these communities, certainly most remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, rely on CDEP as the form of income support for the community. They are not wealthy communities. In the past I have spoken at length in this place about the comparative disadvantage that such communities suffer as a result of their isolation, higher costs and lower income levels when compared with urban communities such as Sydney and Melbourne. It becomes very obvious when you look at schools such as I described earlier: Carey Grammar, Geelong Grammar, Kings School at Parramatta, Scotch College in Melbourne and Adelaide, Knox Grammar, Presbyterian Ladies College and Brighton Grammar School. Just look at the contrast and ask: how can this government justify shifting the public resources that they are seeking to shift in this legislation into those schools as opposed to putting them directly where they are most required—the needier students in Australia, these students who live in these very remote Aboriginal communities?

I thought that, when I came to this place, what I would be doing would be sitting around with others of like mind, not necessarily agreeing on points of principle but at least having a reasonable go at coming to an agreement about what is best for the community. I have heard no argument coming from the government that could convince me—or anyone I know—of the validity of the course of action which the government is seeking to take in this legislation. It will not add to educational outcomes for those people most in need. It will not improve the year 12 retention levels for Aboriginal students in the Northern Territory or the wider Northern Territory school proportion because of the very large proportion of the Northern Territory's school population that goes to public schools. In any event, as I pointed out, not one of the private schools in the Northern Territory is a category 1 school—not one.

It seems to me that, if it is the purpose of members in this place to develop good policy and make good legislation for the people of Australia, then this sadly misses the mark. I am happy to enter into dialogue with members of the government on the best way to achieve and improve educational attainment levels for people in remote Australia. But I have not seen them want to engage in such dialogue. What we have seen here is an ideological fix trumped-up by Minister Kemp 10 years ago, paraded now as government policy and exhibited here in the form of this pernicious piece of legislation that will just create further division within our community. That is not good for us: it is not good for this parliament and it is not good for Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to address an issue which I know will be dear to your heart, Mr Speaker, and that is the publication of the draft basin salinity management strategy for the Murray-Darling Basin. This document has been a long time coming, but we are pleased that it is now out in the public domain for public comment. I am urging all those people with an interest in the issue, of which there are many in the constituency of Mallee, to study this document and to make public comment, which is due by 5 December this year.

speech.para: There are two initiatives in the strategy to tackle the problem of salinity which is so evident right across the Murray-Darling Basin. It is still very much a skeletal framework document which leaves a lot of work yet to be done to put some flesh on the bones, but at least it sets out some very substantial objectives in order to overcome this very pernicious problem that pervades right across the Murray-Darling Basin. It actually affects 18 constituencies of this place. It is a very large part of Australia—one-seventh of the continent, about one million square kilometres, producing about 41 per cent of the nation's horticultural and agricultural wealth. It is a very important issue to the nation.

The central thrust of the strategy is to focus on an integrated catchment management approach to solving our problems. One thing that I think we can be proud of in this place and as a nation is that this will be the largest catchment management program of its kind in the whole world. It is over a million square kilometres. It is important to note that there are many countries around the world that look with great interest on what we are achieving here in Australia in terms of getting all of the state agencies together in a ministerial council to tackle the very serious problems that confront us.

A lot of people are already asking how much it will cost to overcome this pernicious problem we have with salinity and water management. That is a matter that we have yet to establish, but it is certainly in the billions of dollars. It will be a great challenge for this parliament and the government to meet that need.

I am particularly interested in tackling the very serious, and probably awkward, political difficulties in encouraging the amount and the degree of community, government and state involvement in solving our problem. We are all in this boat together. It is not a question of laying blame. The salinity problems in the Murray-Darling Basin have not just happened; it has taken us 120-odd years to see the damage that is now evident. I would not propose that it take us that long to fix it, but it is a very long-term commitment to overcome some of the degradation that has now occurred—unbelievably complex degradation of the biology of our rivers and streams, and massive salinisation because of the incredibly changed nature of the water flows of those valuable rivers and streams right across the basin. There are at least 21 separate rivers and thousands of other streams.

I think that Australia has probably had its wake-up call on this matter. We have had 12 years of sustained low rainfall. The parlous state of the capacity of many of the storages across the basin gives testimony to that, as well as the parlous state of the nature of our rivers and streams. A lot of people say it is all the farmers' fault, with their land management practices and the inappropriate use of water. But it is not the solution just to find people to blame. The nation has benefited immensely from the agricultural investment that has gone on in the last 15 years, and there has been a massive change in the culture of the use of water and the way that land is managed. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Savings Bonus

talk.start.para: —I would like to take the opportunity of talking tonight about an issue of great importance to many older persons in my electorate of Swan. I speak of the recent debacle concerning the aged persons bonus promised to all Australians aged over 60 years. This is particularly relevant as I have recently written to most seniors in my constituency regarding this matter. The facts of this scandalous debacle, where the Prime Minister deliberately misled the Australian community for cheap political gain in the lead-up to the last election, cannot be forgotten and, I am sure, will not be forgiven by the Australian people.

speech.para: In the last two days I have been informed by the staff in my office that they are receiving up to 100 calls per hour—yes, per hour—by people who are appalled and concerned about the Prime Minister's conduct. Many seniors have advised that they received far less than the promised $1,000, and many were confused as to the facts of the Prime Minister's deception. Therefore, I would like to put again on the public record some of the statements made by the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister, in the lead-up to the last election. Firstly, I refer to an interview with John Howard on Radio 6PR in Perth on 25 August 1998. The member for Bennelong said:

quote.para: You get a $1000 savings bonus for all people over the age of 60.

speech.para: At the Carseldine Retirement Village in Brisbane on 18 August 1998, he said:

quote.para: ... for every person 60 and over there will be [a] savings bonus—a one-off tax free payment of $1000 in relation to any investment income that you might have.

speech.para: On A Current Affair on 13 August 1998, he said:

quote.para: ... because you have investment income, you'll get access to the savings bonus which is $1000 for everybody 60 years and over.

speech.para: Yes, the Prime Minister did promise that all people aged over 60 would receive the $1,000. But did he deliver? No. In fact, some 1.3 million Australians received less than a dollar for the double taxation of their savings. To highlight this hardship, I would like to quote from two constituents who contacted my office in the last two days. Mr McPherson of Redcliffe said:

quote.para: Done for, course we are, they can stick it. I didn't get it, they didn't even say I needed money in the bank. I am a pensioner, I'm 76, worked all my bloody life and I've got nothing for it.

speech.para: Mr Riaschilla of Carlisle said:

quote.para: If a pensioner is wealthy and has $10,000 in the bank they get $1000. But if they are poor, have no savings, are sick, well they should get it, they need it ... the GST is for everybody.

speech.para: Others, in response to the mail-out, have returned letters to me requesting that the issue be taken up with the Prime Minister. Mr Dymock of Carlisle, for example, states in a form letter and further on:

quote.para: Before the 1998 Federal election, Mr Howard promised older Australians a $1,000.00 savings bonus.
Now we find that most people have received less that $50.00!
It's wrong that he can make yet another promise to people and then break it.
I would like you to contact Mr. Howard on my behalf and tell him that older Australians expect better of their Prime Minister.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: I am 70 years of age.
I pay rent and live by myself.
I do not own my house, or any property.
I have been informed by Centrelink that I will not be receiving any money—none at all.

speech.para: Many of our Australians are doing it tough. Senior Australians deserve better of their Prime Minister. They do not deserve false promises and misleading statements. It is clear that the Australian public were told untruths in the lead-up to the election, and that has now become clear. That the community knows this and will be taking the government to task in the future is certain. It is time the Prime Minister apologised for his deception, took out the golf clubs and allowed the two Petes, the Phantom and the guard dog lover, to fight over the leadership of the Liberal kennel.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Labor Party: Shadow Aboriginal Affairs Portfolio

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, ABC Radio reported a Labor frontbencher who had likened the job of Aboriginal affairs on the Labor front bench as being like the `toilet cleaner on the Titanic' and also a `poisoned chalice'. The Leader of the Opposition stated yesterday that he would sack the person if he knew who had made the comment. We have heard today that he is not looking very seriously for the culprit. I think that was a disgusting comment, when there is so much to be done in the area of Aboriginal health, education, employment and housing. I congratulate the minister for health on the improvements we have made in the area of Aboriginal health. I congratulate the minister for employment for the initiatives we have taken in the area of indigenous employment.

speech.para: Today, we also heard that if you do a search of ParlInfo you find that the member for Dobell is the only Labor frontbencher who has used both the phrase `poisoned chalice' and also `the Titanic'. I do not actually believe that the member for Dobell was the culprit, as he has confirmed to us that the culprit was a member of the Left. So essentially what we are looking for is a Labor frontbencher who is known for vile language and is also from the Left. If you do a search on ParlInfo for `Titanic', you find that it has been mentioned over 200 times. It is commonly used. There are a number of connotations which you can give to `Titanic' in political language. For example, the Titanic can be heading for an iceberg. You can `shuffle the deckchairs on the Titanic'. But hearing that expression, the image that I had from that movie and from the story of the Titanic was this notion: when someone talks about a toilet cleaner on the Titanic, what I think about is those third class passengers. What I think about are the passengers in steerage who, as we all know, did particularly badly when the Titanic was sunk. When you actually do a search for `Titanic' and `steerage', you come up with one speech, and it is quite an interesting quote. The speech was in the context of the tax reform legislation, in April last year. The quote is:

quote.para: We have seen the grand plan concocted by Mr Howard unravel before his eyes as the flaws in this legislation and the GST have been exposed. The ANTS package is a bit like the Titanic—this huge vessel that might look okay but they have covered up the fact that they have skimped on the lifeboats. What happens when we hit the first economic iceberg? The rich on the top decks will probably be okay, but the steerage passengers are going to drown.

speech.para: Who made that speech? As I understand it, in searching for who came up with this comment the Labor Party have been looking predominantly at the House of Representatives. They should look more at the Senate, because the person who made this speech was Senator Faulkner—Senator Faulkner, known for his colourful language, a member of the Left, a Labor Party frontbencher. The conclusion is inescapable: j'accuse Senator Faulkner.

talk.start.para: —I would comment on the previous speaker's remarks but I have more important matters to talk about. Tonight I rise to speak on a controversial issue in my electorate of Chisholm—the proliferation of telephone towers in our suburbs and the need to balance the needs of telecommunications with those of local residents. This was only a sleeper of an issue when I contested the seat of Chisholm in 1998, but throughout my term I have seen the erection of mobile telephone towers all over the suburbs within my electorate. Most of these towers have been erected on the top of buildings; others more disrespectfully as a part of a cross of a local church.

speech.para: There are two main complaints residents have about the erection of these towers. The first is the genuine fear about the long-term health and safety effects on people exposed to the electromagnetic emissions from mobile towers. Whilst telecommunications companies assure us that towers radiate such a low level of emissions that they are safe, it is not surprising that residents remain unconvinced. There are too many historical examples of conditions that do not show symptoms until years after the initial contact, and mobile phones are a very recent phenomenon. Harmful emissions from direct mobile phone use may well pose a greater risk than those from low impact facilities. However the legitimate concerns of parents and residents must be heard.

The other issue that motivates residents to protest against the towers is the total lack of consultation before these facilities are built. Most mobile towers are considered `low impact facilities'. Therefore they are not subject to local planning laws, nor do the builders even have to inform residents and traders of their intention to install them. Only stand-alone towers require a permit from the local council. Take the example in my electorate where a tower was built in the shape of a cross at the St James Uniting Church in Wattle Park. The church is adjoining a local kindergarten. Only the kindergarten parents were belatedly informed at a last-minute meeting and the church congregation was advised of the impending mobile tower to be erected. However, none of the residents surrounding the church was informed at all, and these are the people who will be living in the presence of this facility 24 hours a day. Many of the residents have become quite outraged about the issue and have organised a petition. Unfortunately, the building of the tower was completed without reference to their views or the impact on their local environment.

The most recent example has been in the northern tip of my electorate in Kerrimuir. Local residents had fought off an attempt by the telecommunications company to install a tower across the road only to have it erected on top of the pharmacy at the local shops. Again the well-organised residents submitted an impressive petition to me with well over 100 signatures opposing the tower. Unfortunately, some of the residents have mistakenly taken their anger out on the chemist who is operating in the shop where the tower has been erected. For the record, the chemist is only a tenant. He does not own the building and had nothing to do with the erection of the tower. He has lost 30 per cent of his business, has had his car vandalised and is facing serious legal problems and financial problems as we speak because of this facility. The person he rents from did not have the decency to advise him that the tower was being installed and the telecommunications company even used his electricity to put up the tower. Local businesses are falling victim to a misdirected buyers strike, another spin-off from the growing problem of telecommunications towers.

What is the answer on the lack of consultation? I was very pleased to see the proposed changes released by Labor's shadow minister for communications, Stephen Smith, on 24 July this year. His statement at the time showed that Labor has listened to the disquiet in the suburbs caused by the lack of consultation. In particular, the changes that will make a difference in my electorate are: requiring carriers to advise and consult with the relevant local authority over the proposed construction of a low impact facility; requiring carriers to share or co-locate proposed or existing facilities on a case by case basis; and providing for the relevant local authority or authorities to seek a determination from the ACA about whether a proposed facility is a high or low impact facility.

These changes may be implemented through a code of conduct enforceable by the ACA or by the government amending the relevant determinations and regulations under the telecommunications legislation. Either way, the key is that these changes must be adopted in an enforceable manner. This will go a long way to quelling public outrage over the lack of consultation. Like most people who lodge planning appeals, residents accept they might lose, but they would at least like the opportunity to be heard.

The industry also needs to look at its own poor handling of these issues. I would have thought it was both good public relations practice and good corporate citizenship to make an attempt to at least inform residents of the installation of a tower in their local area. I note that the government has belatedly realised that the planning framework for the construction of mobile tower facilities must be reformed. However, not enough is being done. I do realise that there is a need to have the infrastructure in our area, but this must be balanced against the rights of consumers. It must be balanced against the genuine fears of parents and residents who are being totally overlooked in this area. There is a growing need for a tighter framework to strike a balance between the needs of the industry and those of the thousands of families out there who deserve a greater say over what happens in their neighbourhood. I commend all the excellent advocacy work done by the various residents in my electorate. I simply ask them to continue raising these issues with me so together we can continue to pressure the government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to inform the House of a very pleasant occasion when I was the guest of Tony Ford, the Chief Executive Officer of the Port Hedland Shire Council, and Geoff Blackman, its Mayor, to attend the official opening of the Dalgety House Museum in Port Hedland on Saturday, 5 August. The Dalgety House Museum has been a development proceeding over a number of years. I will take you back in history. Following the discovery of gold and the opening of the Pilbara goldfield in 1888 with Marble Bar as its centre, Port Hedland was reassessed for shipping as Condon, the port further north, had increased silt problems. The Port Hedland townsite was surveyed in 1895 and the first jetty was built in 1896. By 1900 pearling activity had moved from Condon and, along with tin, wool, stock and gold, formed the basis of the port export activity. The infrastructure of the town began to grow and by 1901 there were two hotels in the town. The Union Bank opened and a second jetty was built.

speech.para: Dalgety House had its origins then. The Dalgety warehouse premises were opened for business in 1903 and it is probably about this time that the manager's house was built. The first occupants of the Dalgety manager's house was, in fact, Russell F. Crowe, who was there from 1903 until 1910. The Port Hedland Historical Society decided in 1999 to adopt the consultancy plan that was drawn up by Sally Anne Hasluck as part of a recommendation of the Western Australian Museum. The office bearers of the Port Hedland Historical Society—Pauline Taylor, President; Liam Clayton, Vice-President; Arnold Carter, Treasurer; and Kay Richardson, Secretary—with the assistance of the Dalgety House Executive Committee—Trish Parker, Saryn Jones, Jenny Durshaw, Michelle Mackenzie, Judith Enright, Julie Hunt and Jeff Schaefer—carried the project through to fruition; a magnificent presentation of a historic manager's residence in the Pilbara of Western Australia. It truly reflects the lifestyle of the day, the merchant style of the day and puts on display the commodities sold by Dalgety in those days. It is a marvellous step back in time to an era when things were slower and the values of things from the outside world were much, much greater. To flip through the invoice books Dalgety issued almost a hundred years ago is a very interesting pastime, I can assure you.

The Port Hedland society therefore, with the support of the community to generate interest in and knowledge of the region, has established the Port Hedland museum. Dalgety House has been restored to portray life in the early isolated settlements of the Pilbara through the story of Port Hedland as the gateway between the world and the hinterland for people, goods and industry. Despite the role of Dalgety's agency, the society seeks, through the formation and interpretation of a museum collection and delivery of public programs, to give residents and visitors an understanding of the growth of the district and the special sense of place. The tourist season is between April and October. Amongst the many spectacles that can be seen there today is evidence of BHP's activities, including its hot briquetted iron plant, and it would make people realise why that harbour is part of one of the most complex harbour arrangements in the Pilbara handling some of the largest tonnages in Australia today. It is a town of which we can be truly proud, part of the modern Pilbara.

talk.start.para: —There is nothing that demonstrates more the Howard government's contempt for the people of Shortland than its decision to close the Belmont Medicare office in 1995. It was a well-utilised office and its closure has caused great hardship to the residents of the area. You can be forgiven for thinking that the office closed simply because it happened to be within a Labor electorate. The Medicare office serviced a number of elderly people, people who do not have drivers licences or have restricted drivers licences. There are a number of elderly people who live within Swansea, which is five kilometres from Belmont, and were able to travel to the Medicare office, but now they have been gravely disadvantaged. There is no Medicare office between Charlestown and Lake Haven, and the Charlestown Medicare office is one of the 10 busiest offices in New South Wales. The staff were recently surveyed and they identified that the reopening of the Belmont Medicare office was the most pressing need and the biggest issue in the area for Medicare. They followed up by saying that they could not understand why it ever closed. It is sadly missed by all.

speech.para: This has recently been compounded by the fact that four of the biggest medical practices in the area have ceased bulk-billing—surprise, surprise. They have instituted a fee scale of $25, and that is $22.50 co-payment and $2.50 out of the patient's own pocket, for pensioners and unemployed people. If they choose to have the doctor send off the form so that they can get a cheque and then give it to the doctor, they are putting in place a $5 charge. This means that people who are least able to afford to pay for medical care are actually being hit with a $5 charge while those people who can manage to wait to get their money back or have got some way of getting to the Medicare office at Charlestown, which is some hour away by public transport if you live in Swansea, where most of the elderly people live, fare better.

Those disadvantaged people are going to be disadvantaged even more. Three of the largest practices in the Shortland electorate actually closed on 1 September, which coincided, not surprisingly, with the government's decision to require doctors to electronically transfer all accounts that they bulk-bill. The government gave the doctors $500 towards the cost of this new technology, and that was nowhere near enough. The doctors were going to be considerably out of pocket. This has not really hit, but over the next four to six weeks, when it really bites, I am very worried that there are going to be more practices that cease bulk-billing and more pensioners and unemployed people who are going to be disadvantaged by this government's policies.

The local GPs in Swansea have actually been trying to employ another doctor for two years. One of the explanations that they gave is that they wanted to dampen the demand for their services, because they have been unable to attract a doctor. This really shows how the government's policy of attracting doctors to regional areas is failing. I was astonished to hear the minister say in question time last week that bulk-billing was not declining. It has certainly drastically declined in the Shortland electorate. If the minister cares to look at the figures, he will see that I am right. Shortland is an area, as I have already said, with an elderly population that is being disadvantaged not only by losing a well-utilised Medicare office but also by local doctors deciding not to bulk-bill.

I am so concerned about this that I have called a public meeting to discuss the issue of bulk-billing and the closure of our Medicare office. The government's attack on bulk-billing and Medicare is hurting the most disadvantaged people in our community: pensioners, unemployed, the old, the fragile and the people with disabilities. This is a major issue of community health. This government is failing to act on it. This government is disadvantaging the people of the Shortland electorate, and I am certainly going to see that their voice is heard. We are going to work to have that Medicare office reopened and have the government change its policy on bulk-billing. It is just not good enough.

talk.start.para: —Protecting the health of the Murray-Darling Basin is a shared responsibility, not one of laying blame. It is a partnership between state and federal governments, communities and industries, who will have to commit their time, expertise, knowledge and effort as well as their finances. The new approach outlined in two documents, the draft Integrated Catchment Management Policy Statement and the draft Basin Salinity Management Strategy, recognises that many activities are going to be needed to protect catchment health and that the implementation of the salinity strategy will have a public as well as a private benefit. Therefore, investment will rely on a mix of both public and private sources of investment. The documents outline principles for government investment as well as those designed to trigger private investment, a lot of which is already occurring, especially in the horticultural sector as it gets towards more scientifically based and sophisticated irrigation technology. Over the next decade land-holders and industries will be encouraged to improve their land and water management practices in line with the local catchment plan, and in some areas to change their land use. The changes will aim to achieve catchment health targets as set out in these documents and to ensure the economic and social wellbeing of the catchment communities, of which there are a great many out there.

speech.para: Land-holders are not the only people who will be affected. Governments and catchment management organisations will need to change the way they do their business so that they can support and guide the changes on the ground. There is an enormous amount of science being collected that will need to be continued. It is not just people in rural environments either—urban people across the nation are affected by the nation's natural resources and particularly the way in which they are managed. Adelaide, for example, depends on the waters of the Murray River for drinking and other purposes. In fact, nearly 40 per cent of the Murray River's water is used to supply valuable water to townships and communities outside the basin area itself. This particular urban centre of Canberra depends on the basin, and it is the largest population centre in the entire basin. For those reasons urban Australians will be asked to share in the cost of protecting the basin. This will most often be through investment of public funds, but a substantial amount of investment will be from the private sector. The approach outlined in the two documents deserves the community's attention, and I hope there will be a large number of people making worthwhile contributions. It is to the nation's benefit, the benefit of our generation and the benefit of subsequent generations.

talk.start.para: —I thank the previous speaker for his consideration in giving me a couple of minutes. Tomorrow marks the 60th anniversary of the arrival in Australia of the famous refugee ship the Duneera. Tomorrow at the National Maritime Museum in Darling Harbour I will congratulate Mr Henry Lipman and Count Oswald Wolkenstein, who have organised the 60th anniversary reunion, which will probably be the last reunion of people from this famous refugee ship.

speech.para: I thought I would relate to the House a very interesting comment that Mr Lipman made to me in the many discussions we have had prior to the 60th anniversary—the essential decency of Australia and British style democracy which these people came to. He said that the people of the Duneera, as is well known in the story of that ship, received some terrible treatment from the soldiers who were on the ship and who did not differentiate between the Nazis who were being transported by British forces and the refugees on the ship. All of their documents were thrown overboard. Many people suggest that this was the reason that they were not sunk by German U-boats, as the German U-boats picked up these German documents. Mr Lipman said that it was a great credit to Britain and to Australian democracy that these soldiers were court-martialled and cashiered even during the war that Britain was fighting against Germany at that time.

These can be found in Aerodromes, Annex 14 to the Convention on International Civil Aviation, Chapter 9, dated 4 November 1999, as “International Standards and Recommended Practices”. The ICAO Rescue and Fire Fighting Standards do not regulate the provision of the service but establish standards and recommended practices.
Australian Rescue and Fire Fighting Services regulations are currently being developed by CASA.

CASA advises that the current Australian practice is in compliance with ICAO standards and provides RFFS for the arrival and departure of scheduled international passenger flights, with the exception of Christmas Island where a standards difference has been filed with ICAO due to remoteness of the island and the frequency of aircraft operations.

CASA advises that Ayers Rock airport is not required to provide RFFS as the airport does not meet the current criterion for the provision of the services. In addition, the flight carrying the Olympic Torch is regarded as a special one-off flight and not as a standard international passenger transport flight.

(4) CASA advises that as Ayers Rock Airport does not meet the criterion for the provision of RFFS, and as the flight was not regarded as a standard international passenger transport flight, Rescue and Fire Fighting Services were not provided.

CASA was consulted on the use of Ayers Rock Airport for the flight on 25 May 2000. CASA indicated it had no objection to Ayers Rock being designated an international airport to permit a service by an Ansett A320 to travel from Auckland to Ayers Rock direct on 8 June 2000 carrying the Olympic Flame.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did the Privacy Commissioner recently undertake discussions with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in respect of the disclosure of the Australian Business Number (ABN) information.
(2) What concerns motivated the Privacy Commissioner to undertake those discussions.
(3) Did the Privacy Commissioner conduct an investigation in respect of those concerns; if not, why not.

(4) Did the Privacy Commissioner conclude that the disclosure by the ATO of the ABN was lawful under the A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Act, when the Privacy Commissioner had not conducted an investigation in respect to the disclosure; if so, on what basis was the conclusion reached.
(5) Did the Privacy Commissioner request the ATO to modify its conduct and practices; if so, on what basis was the request made.
(6) What was the final outcome of the discussions between the Privacy Commissioner and the ATO and what action has the ATO undertaken as a result of those discussions.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. The Privacy Commissioner has advised me that his Office held a number of discussions with the ATO in respect of the collection, use and disclosure of ABN information.
(2) The Privacy Commissioner has advised me that the following concerns motivated his Office to undertake those discussions:
(a) whether the information collected involved personal information;
(b) whether the ATO complied with Information Privacy Principle 2 contained in s.14 of the Privacy Act 1988 when it solicited the ABN information from the individual concerned; and
(c) whether in releasing information to Dunn & Bradstreet the ATO had complied with the Information Privacy Principles.

(3) No. The Privacy Commissioner has advised me that on this occasion he did not conduct a formal investigation pursuant to his powers under s.40(2) of the Privacy Act 1988. It has been a long standing practice of his Office to conduct preliminary enquiries with the relevant agency and then seek to conciliate outcomes wherever possible. This approach has proved very effective over the ten years of operation of the Privacy Act 1988.

(4) The Privacy Commissioner has advised me that his preliminary enquiries confirmed his Office's view that the disclosure was authorised pursuant to the A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Act 1999 and therefore lawful. The Privacy Commissioner has also advised me that he was satisfied that the disclosure of ABN information was made pursuant to a contractual agreement entered into by the ATO and Dunn & Bradstreet which contained stringent privacy and confidentiality terms and conditions.

(5) Yes. The Privacy Commissioner has advised me that during his preliminary enquiries, he advised the ATO that the IPP 2 statement only partially complied with the requirements of IPP 2 as the statement was scattered throughout both the electronic and hard copy ABN application information guides. The Privacy Commissioner suggested that the ATO modify its conduct and practices in order to better administer its privacy obligations.
As a result of those discussions the ATO agreed to:

(a) review current wording on website and paper documents to improve notice to individuals as to what will be done with their personal information and to ensure better compliance with IPP 2. The ATO also agreed to seek the Privacy Commissioner's input and assistance in this process;
(b) consult closely with the Privacy Commissioner in relation to any future bulk release of ABN records;
(c) examine options to recommend to Government, including the possibility of an opt-out option that would limit access to personal information associated with the ABN; and
(d) consult with the Privacy Commissioner in relation to any changes to the Regulations associated with the A New Tax System (Australian Business Number) Act 1999.
(6) The Privacy Commissioner has advised me that on 22 June 2000 the Privacy Commissioner reached agreement with the ATO in relation to the resolution of:
(a) the wording to be used in its IPP 2 statement;
(b) the location of the IPP 2 statement on its website and in ABN registration packages;
(c) the appropriate wording to be used in bulk data licence agreements to ensure that stringent privacy safeguards are in place;
(d) the development of draft principles for considering requests to suppress public access to personal information; and
(e) a letter to be sent by the Commissioner of Taxation to all existing registrants to inform them of the measures undertaken to ensure the protection of their privacy.
